PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 10 a.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: SYDNEY 2000 GAMES (INDICIA AND IMAGES) PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September 1996, on motion by Mr McGauran:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me indicate quite obviously that the opposition does not oppose the amendment to the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996. Quite the opposite: obviously, it is important that manufacturers and retailers of approved material which bears any of the symbols of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games be offered protection. The simple fact is that this amendment—which comes, I might say, pretty quickly after the passage of the original bill itself—does go to the need to add a couple more protections.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue at heart here is that the amendments enable Olympic Games organisers and licensed users to take action against retailers, distributors and parties in the supply chain, rather than having to pursue through the supply chain the unauthorised person who applied the indicia or images to goods and services. That really is what it is all about: you can simply take the action against whoever is illegally putting out material.

There is no doubt that in any Olympic Games—and certainly it will be the case in Sydney, as was demonstrated from Atlanta—the opportunity for people to recoup considerable sums of investment will come by the retailing of products. Therefore, the importance of having some security on the images and on those products themselves—knowing that the return will go to the specific people who manufacture them under licence—so that there is a return that goes back to the organising committees, is quite appropriate. As I have indicated, we have no objection to the purposes contained in this amendment.

I did want to ask one question, though, and I would be pleased if the parliamentary secretary would take this matter on board. It arises out of the whole idea behind the use of the word `Olympics'. One of my colleagues, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), has asked me just to seek clarification on whether the term `Olympic Village', which I understand applies to a nursing home in West Heidelberg, is in fact going to be affected by this bill, and whether they are going to have to change the name of their organisation. It is a community group or a school: I am not quite sure what it is, but certainly the term `Olympic Village' is used. I said to my colleague that the answer was no, and that they can continue to use it, just as Olympic Airways continues to fly under that logo, and so on. I see officials nodding in the background. That will be good enough for me, so the parliamentary secretary does not need to worry about it. I thank the officers for that confirmation, and I will pass it on to the member for Jagajaga.

I want to say one or two more general things. As somebody who is the shadow spokesman for the Olympic Games, I take a great deal of interest in the media coverage of the lead‐up to this very special event and, quite frankly, I have to say that I get sick to death of some of the media in this country pursuing angles about the development of the year 2000 games from a negative perspective. Nothing demonstrates this more than when the announcement was made and the unveiling took place of the three caricatures of Australian animals to be the symbols for the year 2000 games.

The next day, one of the Sydney dailies ran an analysis piece by an anthropologist or a zoologist, or something or other, that talked about the fact that the representations of those animals really were not drawn to scale and were not drawn properly, and that the personalities that were ascribed to those three particular characters were not appropriate. One was supposed to be fun loving, one was supposed to be a bit sporting and I forget what the other one was. To me, it just seemed so nonsensical that what I thought were three excellent representations of Australia to be the mascots for the Olympics in the year 2000 were subjected to this sort of analysis in one of the Sydney newspapers.

People do not seem to be going out of their way to promote the positives of the games. What they seem to be doing is looking for a way in which they can put a negative on every aspect of it. For example, I know that when they were talking about trying to settle down the executive positions in SOCOG and who was going to take the next rung down of management, criticism was coming out that it was taking too long to do that. There has been some criticism that perhaps the construction of some of the infrastructure is not on target, and so on.

There are bound to be some hiccups in the development of a project of this scale and magnitude. But the benefit that ultimately will come to Australia outweighs any of those sorts of concerns. SOCOG and, I am sure, the Paralympics organising committee take to heart some of those criticisms. So, too, does the Olympics minister in New South Wales, Michael Knight, who—as I am sure my friend the parliamentary secretary opposite would know—absolutely throws his heart and soul into this particular project. He lives and breathes nothing but the Olympics.

As a consequence of this constant harping by certain elements of the media about the perceived negative aspects that could be put on any of these announcements, I would think some of those journalists, if they are operating under instructions, should kick up a fuss. If they think they are getting a name for themselves by doing this, they should have a good hard look at themselves and not ask zoologists, anthropologists or psychologists whether or not the Olympic emblems are appropriate and whether they have the personalities that were supposedly ascribed to them.

The indicia and images that go with the Olympic Games are just so important, as we saw in Atlanta. Quite frankly, the symbol for Atlanta was just a dead loss; I do not think too many people thought it was flash at all. I think the symbol for the Sydney games is very good. I know some people talk about it in negative terms and, as I said, you will find people who do that when it is announced, rather than simply say that it is something that represents Sydney and Australia. Similarly, when we talk about logos that come out, people always seem to want to look at some way in which they should be knocked. I think they must not have too much else to do with their time.

The Olympic Games is going to be a substantial event in Australia's history and the benefits which will flow to Australia because of it will be outstanding. I again indicate to the committee that we have absolutely no objections to the proposals contained in this amendment. I wish it speedy passage through this place and I commend the government for taking the necessary action to protect those retailers and others who have paid considerable sums of money for the rights to produce material for the Olympics that contain the appropriate logos, and so on. They deserve the protection of this legislation.

BREAK.PARA: The main legislation has a sunset clause which concludes not long after the Olympics. Again, that is appropriate. It saves us from a lot of shonky people being out there and from a lot of material being dumped in Australia now, in the lead‐up to the Olympic Games and during the games. We support the amendment wholeheartedly. I notice the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) has just came in. I have made a couple of comments about logos, and so on, and I suggest that he read Hansard at some stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity given by this indicia and images protection amendment bill to make a few comments about the 2000 Olympics and I would endorse the remarks of the member for Cunningham and shadow minister. I think it is very important for all of us in public life to get behind the Olympics and make them great.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall a few years ago, my former boss John Hewson saying that he strongly supported Sydney's bid for the 2000 Olympics because it would make us fix up the largest city in the country. It would impose a deadline on us before which we would have to put Sydney in tiptop shape. Now we have got the Olympics. That is fantastic, and I guess today I want to pose the question: are we doing enough to make Sydney a great national showcase as we Australians go on display before the world? What is going to happen in the year 2000 is not simply two weeks in summer, but a decade of economic opportunity. It is a once in a lifetime opportunity and I have a terrible feeling that in some important respects we might be letting it slip through our fingers.

I know that the tempo of construction has recently been lifted at Homebush Bay and I congratulate the New South Wales authorities and the organising committee for all their hard work in this regard. I think there is little doubt that the Olympic site will be in absolutely top condition. It will be a great state. It will be a great site. We will have a great stadium. We will have a great village. But the question is, will we have a great city? I speak not as a planner, not as an engineer, not as a sports administrator, certainly not as a parliamentary secretary; I speak simply as an Australian and as a Sydneysider. I do not speak as an expert. I speak as an interested and concerned layman because it is not Sydney's Olympics, it is Australia's Olympics. It is a great national project; it is not just a big local project.

I am sure that people coming to this country from overseas will give us a big A for running the actual Olympics themselves. Will they give us a big A for running our country? I am sure that they will conclude, having been here in the run-up, in the duration, and in the aftermath of the olympics that we are good sports. But will they conclude that we are also good organisers?

The trouble is you get off the plane at Mascot and you try to get yourself to Homebush Bay and you are instantly stuck in a maze of suburban streets and, worse than that, you are stuck in what can only be described as inner city alleyways. You get off the plane at Mascot and try to go to the city—well, thanks to the former New South Wales government we will soon have a railway line, and I congratulate the former government for that. Thanks to the current New South Wales government, if environmental approvals go as they should—as I believe they should—we will have a decent eastern distributor and I congratulate the current New South Wales government for that. But if you try to get from the city to Homebush Bay by car—and let us face it not everyone will go by train and very few people will be able to go by ferry—you are not going to be able to do it easily. You will get stuck in the same maze of suburban byways, in the same back alleys which sadly have afflicted our city and its transport for generations.

It is not fair to say of Sydney that it is a first world city with a third world infrastructure, but it certainly is not true to say that we really are in a tiptop standard for the end of the 20th century. We have freeways and tollways that come to dead ends in the middle of residential areas. We have arterial roads designed for the 1950s carrying the traffic of the 1990s. We have a rail system which has not been significantly expanded for 60 years. In my own area, we have had suggestions for transport improvement dating back to the 1870s—would you believe—when the first suggestion for a rail line to Warringah was made. In the 1930s, Bradfield, the engineer who designed the Sydney Harbour Bridge, wanted to put a railway through to the Warringah peninsular. That did not get anywhere. In the 1970s we were going to extend the Warringah expressway. That did not get anywhere.
In the late 1980s and early 1990s the former state government set up a section 22, a transport planning committee. In the end that broke up with inconclusive results.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The parliamentary secretary has now been speaking for five minutes on very interesting material but I suggest he come to the content of the bill because, as yet, he has not said one word relevant to the bill.

—Indeed I have, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I am about to get to the bill. I will be very brief. In Seoul, in 1988, an entire underground rail system was designed and built in the three years leading up to the Olympics. I would like to think that anything that they can do we can at least attempt to do. It is very important that we try to do everything we possibly can to ensure that Sydney is a great national showcase.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard the New South Wales Premier speak frequently about the Olympics, and he speaks very well about the Olympics. But I think it is time that we had Bob Carr's vision not just for the Olympic site but for the whole Olympic city. If he would like to give people a lead, I am sure lots of people would like to rally around to help.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I give my wholehearted support to the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Amendment Bill 1996. This bill is a refinement by amendment of the principal act which was introduced prior to the Atlanta Games. This amendment bill makes the operation of the principal act much more effective because action can be taken against retailers, distributors and/or parties in the supply chain rather than there being a series of long, costly and potentially forlorn pursuits against unauthorised persons who apply the indicia or images to goods and services.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment bill also allows SOCOG, SPOC and licensed users to take action against those who aid, abet, counsel and procure breaches of the legislation. The amendments are very important because they enable swift action to be taken against ambush marketeers who initiate the unlicensed use of the indicia or images, those in the retail supply chain standing to benefit commercially from such illegal use, and the professional urgers who help the ambush marketeers to get their unlicensed product to market.

Images for these games are of special importance and personal interest to me because Syd, Olly and Millie, the Sydney 2000 Games mascots, were in fact designed by my nephew, Matthew Hatton. He does not stand to personally gain from this legislation because his graphic design was done on a contract basis but those who are in copyrighted receipt of the application of his genius—SOCOG, SPOC, and the licensed users of the mascot images—will gain legislated protections which will enable ambush marketing to be swiftly dealt with.

BREAK.PARA: Matthew Hatton's graphic design and the work of the team who worked with him to bring those designs to reality have created simple, powerful, vivacious and strong Olympic mascots for these games, and they make a wonderful marketing tool for the Sydney 2000 games. The radiant energy of this trio allied to their appealing nature will allow SOCOG to project these images as indicative of the vital, fresh, innovative and friendly games that will usher in the new millennium. SOCOG's capacity to generate the income they expect from the use and production of these images, of the mascots and their associated use in other media, needs the protection afforded by this amendment bill and those of the principal act.

The Sydney 2000 Games now has a cheerful, friendly and dynamic trio of ambassadors to ignite overseas interest in the uniqueness of Australia and Sydney's Games. Syd, Olly and Millie are a potential goldmine for SOCOG and licensed users of these images. They have to be protected from pirates and privateers who, without compensation to the copyright owners, SOCOG, would seek great commercial benefit from their unauthorised use.

The danger of such illegal use is far greater with these creations than with mascots made for previous Olympics. Even if one looks in a most generous spirit at some past efforts—Atlanta's Izzy or the Munich Games' dachshund—one would not think that they were a marketeer's dream. In fact, the disaster that was the Montreal Olympics, where the people of that city will continue to pay the cost of those Olympics well into the next century, was probably added to by the fact that the mascot was a rather nondescript furry ball that possibly was a beaver.

However, only a few of the previous efforts had the spark and vital essence that allowed them to be highly marketable—and LA's eagle was a notable example. I commend the team which worked with Matthew to realise the mascots for these Games. They have produced a brilliant, innovative, highly marketable and appealing product. The revenues to SOCOG, SPOC and the licensed users should and will be protected by this amendment bill and the principal act.

I am concerned, however, that the provisions contained in this bill and the principal act will cease to operate after 31 December 2000. I understand the logic and the unstated rationale behind the decision that there will be no further need for protection provisions once the Games have finished. However, this is short‐sighted. The marketability of Syd, Olly and Millie will not cease with the Games. I believe that they will be so well established and so definitive an expression of the spirit and nature of the Sydney 2000 Games that they will continue to be of commercial benefit to SOCOG at the start of the new millennium on 1 January 2001.

These characters will continue to spawn uses in a wide range of media in the new millennium. They will have the iconic force of the characters invented by May Gibbs and the larrikin appeal of Blinky Bill and his mates. They should continue to be protected from unlicensed profiteering after the Games are over. To not do so would be to deprive SOCOG of ongoing revenue to underwrite the Games into the next century.

The rights and protections granted by this bill and the principal act lay a very firm basis for SOCOG to argue its case with the International Olympic Committee for the extension of protection to other countries. That is extremely important. They are now taking steps in that direction because, if the indicia and images protected in Australia are to gain revenue from overseas so that overseas companies not affected by our legislation could use the indicia and the images to affect and produce goods that would be used in Australia and compete with what is being done here, that could have a detrimental effect on the revenues available here. However, if the International Olympic Committee, in the light of the principal act and the amendments and the arguments put forward by SOCOG, grants rights in other countries, the income for SOCOG generated by that would be very important.

I put my support behind that, and I ask for the parliament's support. I commend the minister for bringing in the principal act and for this amendment bill. It is extremely timely. It will underwrite the importance of all that has been put together and the hard work that everyone has done to ensure that these Games will not cause great grief to the people of New South Wales in terms of providing for the costs of those Games.

It ensures that the people who pay their money to become licensed users of those indicia and images will be properly protected and that the ambush marketeering that was evident at a number of Games will be cut back markedly. We can expect that they will still try to do it, but the force of the principal act and this bill mean that it will be very difficult for them to do so. I commend the bill, and hope it has a swift passage through the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The organisation of the Olympic Games is a massive undertaking, involving massive amounts of expenditure on materials, staff and organisation of all the associated paraphernalia that has come to be associated with the Games. The Sydney Games will be an absolutely magnificent spectacle. I am sure we all accept that. While we look at it now and think there is so much to do, over time, as all of the workmen complete their tasks, as all of the organisers finetune what they are doing, we know that we are moving to that great event in the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of that, it is important to finetune legislation, which is important to facilitate the proper marketing of the games. It is sometimes forgotten that the games will be, in terms of organisation, a massive undertaking. At the same time the finer details are sometimes overlooked in that rush to get things finished, get things organised and get things up and running. It important that, in this case, the government has consulted with a wide range of people and has taken and drawn upon the experience of the Atlanta games, particularly with what occurred in relation to the ambush marketing there.

Just briefly, as has been explained by the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton), ambush marketing really amounts to the unauthorised association of businesses with the marketing of the games without paying for the marketing rights. At times, one almost cringes at the amount of commercialisation that has become associated with the games. That has occurred over many games. If one looks at the Olympic Games of 1956, it is easy to say that was a magnificent spectacle too. But with the overall commercial infrastructure, the marketing, the organising, the television and so forth, all of that has become more and more pronounced over at least probably the last 15 to 20 years. Now we have a massive undertaking in terms of the cost of organising the games, of putting in the capital infrastructure and merely providing all of those things that make for a great games. So, in this day and age, it is necessary to ensure that those who are using the symbols, and are trying to profit by them, pay for them because of the cost that other people and governments have had to bear in getting this thing up and running.

For example, it is estimated that it is going to cost about $2 billion to stage the games. That may even be slightly on the conservative side, and it is going to be shared by the organising committees and the NSW and Commonwealth governments. It is expected, for example, that the Commonwealth government's overall allocation will be of the order of $400 million. It is also expected that the revenue that needs to be raised in addition to government contributions will be in excess of $700 million in order to complete that process.

So it is no mean feat and that really has to be recognised, particularly by businesses. Certainly, we will have no problem with those who are scrupulous. But there are always those who are lurking on the side, as we found from Atlanta, trying to get in to take their share of the market but not pay their fair share of the royalty, if I can put it that way. That was certainly demonstrated, as I said, in Atlanta where two international organisations did not have licensing agreements with the Atlanta organisers but attracted large numbers of people to their respective sports pavilions and the interactive theatre while implying that somehow or other they were part of the games. One did see this a bit during the staging of the Commonwealth Games. There were people on the sides who were not paying their fair due, their fair share or any sort of royalty to the organisers—who were putting in the money, the time and the infrastructure costs—yet these people were benefiting and sometimes reaping significant financial rewards.

This is not going to be a financial bonanza for the organisers and for the governments. There are going to be significant costs for which the funds have to be found. Taxpayers are going to be asked to contribute but I think the majority of Australians want to contribute and want to see a successful games. As we see already in Sydney, even though the games are more than three years away, there is a certain excitement about the prospect of the games. There is a certain buoyancy in the New South Wales economy, particularly in the Sydney area, in real estate and all of those things.

As part of that process, the bill is designed to ensure that those who are perhaps going to trade on the edges are not going to be escaping through the safety net and avoiding their respective responsibilities to contribute their share. When one looks at all of that and, at the same time, embraces the reality of the commercialism of the games, it is quite clear that it is necessary to have this legislation and eventually reach the conclusion that we need to have a successful games, a games that will be doing Australia proud.

I come from Brisbane, the city that staged the Commonwealth Games, and I am proud to say that there are in my electorate a number of present and potential Olympians who will also be part of this process and who will also be relying on the revenue collected to be able to come to the games. They will need the support of the organising committees, and this particular proposal is garnering that support in terms of the dollars and cents that will be needed. It is obviously clear, too—and I have no difficulty with this—that a certain rivalry has occurred over the years between Brisbane and Sydney; but the beauty of the games is that we are shedding that rivalry and are now having a certain unity right across the nation, and this bill is a recognition that we need to get together to achieve those ends.

I am particularly proud to say that I hope that people such as Sharon Cripps, who was an Olympian in my electorate, will also be running in the Sydney 2000 Games, as will the Paralympians, a number of whom are in my electorate, who will also need that support. Remember too, that this is not just a games for people of whole body. Paralympians will also be running and swimming and all of the rest of it, and will be involved in this thing; and so we have got to be behind all of those athletes. As part of that process, we must recognise that this legislation is ensuring that there will be a successful games, that people will be required to contribute fairly, and that no profit takers and no racketeers on the side will be taking away the gloss that I am sure the games will give to the country.

BREAK.PARA: I commend this bill and I commend the thoughts behind the amendment to the particular act. I believe that this—amongst many other projects along the way, legislatively, administratively and, of course, on the ground—will contribute to a wonderful games for Sydney and Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the next member to speak, I remind all members that, while the subject of the Olympic Games is one that excites us all, the content of this bill is very narrow and remarks should be relevant to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I comment in particular in relation to the details of the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Amendment Bill 1996, I would like to congratulate the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who is in the chamber today, on his extended effort in the management of the preparation for Sydney 2000, since I know from first‐hand experience that the development of the proposals and preparations for the Sydney Olympic Games and the Paralympic Games is a mammoth logistical process. I know that all of his efforts and the efforts of his department are significant in relation to that preparation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Amendment Bill 1996, which relates to both the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games and the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games, is primarily concerned with the preservation of the financial integrity of the Sydney games by facilitating licensing revenue through the protection of the use of indicia and images associated with the games. Without such protection, there is a serious threat of the loss of critically important revenue, as the value derived from being licensed to use the indicia and images may be reduced by what is known as ambush or parasitic marketing.

These forms of marketing are essentially the unauthorised association of businesses with the marketing of the Olympic Games. By `unauthorised', I mean that the relevant governing bodies—in our case, the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, known as SOCOG, and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee Limited, known as SPOC—have not sanctioned or licensed, directly or indirectly, the association. As a result, the effectiveness of an official sponsor's message is weakened or ambushed. This may seriously undermine the attracting of further licensed corporate sponsorship. Moreover, ambush marketing clearly threatens the overall integrity of a specific event.

Ambush marketing tactics have unfortunately become commonplace in large sporting events, including the Olympic Games. Some of the well known cases of alleged ambush marketing at recent Olympics include the 1988 Seoul Olympics where one of the world's largest beverage companies carried out a marketing campaign to, `Send the families of US athletes to Seoul'. Although this tactic may have implied an association with the Seoul games, the company at issue had not paid the organising body to act as an official sponsor.

A second example refers to the Nike-Reebok sneakers war at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. Reebok was the official uniform supplier to the US team. However, certain members of the gold medal Olympic basketball team, the `Dream team' as it was known, who had personal sponsorships with Nike, threatened to boycott the medal presentation ceremonies if forced to wear the official Reebok team uniform.

A further example is the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games when Wendys hamburger restaurant chain, a competitor of official sponsor McDonald's, purchased over $8 million worth of United States television air time during the telecast of the games. If you would like to get an indication of just how significant that purchase would be, during the recent Superbowl a 30-second commercial cost around $500,000 for air time, and up to $3 million. That is for a most significant event, so it was significant air time. Wendys used this air time to run commercials depicting spoofs of winter sports.

Two years earlier at the 1992 Winter Games in Albertville, Wendys had engaged in similar tactics by featuring Olympic gold medal figure skater, Kristi Yamaguci, in its television ads during the games. Wendys has learnt that ambush marketing can be terribly effective. A post‐games poll conducted by a leading market research company found that 57 per cent of all respondents incorrectly identified Wendys rather than McDonald's as the official sponsor of the games.

Ambush marketing strategies were also a problem at the Atlanta games last July. Fuji Photo Film, although not an official sponsor of the games, erected billboards primarily in the Atlanta area featuring Olympic decathlete Dan O'Brien. According to the Wall Street Journal, the United States Olympic Committee, the equivalent of our AOC, successfully persuaded Fuji to hide its logo on these billboards.

A further example of ambush marketing tactics arising out of the Atlanta games, and Olympic organising committee vigilance in response to these tactics, related to the activities of the US Postal Service. Although not an official sponsor of the games, several months before the games the US Postal Service announced a marketing program involving Olympic stamps. In an effort to protect the interests of an official sponsor, United Parcel Service, the US Olympic Committee threatened to file a lawsuit against the US Postal Service. The US Postal Service, of course, ultimately backed down before any suit was filed.

Today's Olympic Games are big business. Corporate sponsorship is one of the most critical forms of revenue raising for the games, although it is a relatively new phenomenon for the modern Olympics. According to an article published recently in Sloan Management Review, the first modern Olympic Games in 1896 were largely funded, around 67 per cent, by private donations with the balance coming from stamps, tickets, coins and medals.

It was not until 1956 that the first Olympic Games were televised. By contrast, over 80 per cent of the revenues from Lillehammer and the Atlanta games were derived from television rights and sponsorship. In fact, as recently as 20 years ago it was seriously debated within the International Olympic Committee whether that organisation had any business soliciting corporate sponsorships.

The 1976 summer games in Montreal marked a real turning point in this regard, serving as the first Olympic Games whose organisers sought out, albeit ineffectually, corporate sponsors. Their efforts were less than effectual because the province of Quebec was left with a deficit of over $1 billion after the games and the taxpayers of that province will not repay that debt in full until 2005.

If we take a look at some figures from Montreal we can appreciate how much has changed in the past 20 years. According to the Wall Street Journal, Montreal's organisers sold 628 sponsorships for the paltry sum of $7 million. US television rights to the games were sold for $US25 million. This is no less than astounding based on today's going rate. US television rights to the Atlanta games alone sold for more than $US450 million. That is eighteen times the Montreal amount. Illustrating a continuation of this trend, in 1995 the IOC negotiated an astounding $US4 billion contract for the US television rights alone to the Olympic Games through to the year 2008.

BREAK.PARA: It is therefore an established fact within the IOC that the games mean big business. At the same time, however, the IOC has made it clear that it takes a harsh view on ambush marketing. In 1993, a marketing executive of the IOC was quoted as saying that ambush marketing is not a game; it is a dearly serious business and one that has the potential to destroy sponsorship and one which, if left unchecked, undermines the fundamental revenue base of sport.

Indeed, the host city contract for the Sydney games requires that the host country provide adequate protection for official sponsors. The cost of hosting the Sydney games will be somewhere between $A2 and $A3 billion. The cost of our games, however, will be shared between the organising committees and the Commonwealth and state governments. Although SOCOG plans to sign about half the number of sponsors that supported the Atlanta games, the organising committee is nevertheless expected to raise approximately $700 million through official licensing and sponsorship fees.

SOCOG has so far done an excellent job in attracting over $500 million in sponsorship agreements. According to SOCOG's chief executive officer, Dr Mal Hemmerling, that is not only 12 months ahead of SOCOG's revenue raising schedule, but also the first time that any organising committee has been so far ahead.

These sponsors include some of Australia's leading companies such as Westpac, Telstra, BHP, Westfield, AMP, Energy Australia and Ansett Australia. For their generous and exclusive support of Sydney 2000, these companies deserve protection from ambush marketing activities.

In June 1996, this parliament legislated the principal act, which authorises SOCOG and SPOC to use and to license others to use indicia and images associated with the Sydney games. The principal act incorporated many of the recommendations set forth in Cashing in on the Sydney olympics: protecting the Sydney Olympic Games from ambush marketing, a report presented by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee in March 1995.

The government recognised the importance of putting in place a principal act before the start of the Atlanta games in July 1996. However, at that time the government recognised that the legislation may require some amendment. As the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism noted in the second reading speech for this bill, having the principal act in place in June 1996 permitted SOCOG and SPOC to take advantage of the significant marketing opportunities associated with the Atlanta games. The government also believed that amending the legislation at a later date ensured that there was sufficient time for consultation with the organising committees as well as those groups which will be most affected by the amendments.

For trade and domestically produced goods, the principal act permits action only against the unlicensed entity who actually uses the Sydney games indicia and images for commercial purposes. The government believes that the act, as it stands, may therefore make it difficult to effectively control ambush marketing activities. The amendments set forth in this bill extend the potential liability to retailers, distributors and other parties in the unauthorised entity's supply chain. In addition, the amendments enable the Sydney organising committees and licensees to take action against those who aid, abet, counsel and procure breaches of the legislation.

The changes in the legislation mean that retailers and distributors of goods bearing the Sydney games indicia and images will need to ensure that the persons who apply the indicia and images are licensed to do so. To facilitate compliance with these provisions, the legislation provides that a register of licensed users shall be regularly available for inspection.

The SOCOG has proposed additional measures to ensure public awareness of the legislation as it relates to the use of the Sydney games indicia and images. For example, SOCOG proposes to disseminate widely a list of licensed users. Retail and other affected industry associations have agreed to cooperate with the games organising committees in the dissemination of this information.

While the legislation does put additional burdens on retailers and distributors of goods bearing images of the games, the government believes that the legislation represents a balanced and workable solution that addresses the interests of all affected parties in a fair and reasonable manner, and without placing an undue burden on commerce. These changes to the legislation are proposed after significant consultation with the games organisers and other interest groups. As the minister indicated in the second reading speech for this bill, we are confident that the organising committees and the affected industries will work together in a cooperative manner which will add to the effectiveness of this legislation.

It is worth noting that neither the principal act nor the amendment bill operate to prohibit entities from exercising their existing rights under Australia's intellectual property laws. In addition, neither the principal act nor the amendment bill prohibit entities from using the Sydney games indicia or images to provide factual information or for the purposes of criticism or discussion. For example, the legislation would not prohibit athletes from using the Sydney games indicia and images for the purposes of providing a factual description of their activities in the games. To take that one step further, should Shane Warne become a decathlete in Sydney in 2000 he will be able to wear his Nike earring as part of the festivities of the games.

There will be 10,000‐odd athletes at the games and millions of television viewers around the world, and I believe all of us here today are aware that the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games and the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games are events of the utmost significance, not just for the city of Sydney, but for all Australians. That includes the people of North Sydney who will participate in this event in a quite extraordinary way. The most significant event of the Olympics, the one that dates back to the time of ancient Greece, is the marathon run. On 1 October 2000, at probably a very early hour I would imagine, given the heat of Sydney at that time, the gun will go off in North Sydney for the beginning of the marathon, which will pass over the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and hopefully all the marathon runners will make it into the Homebush stadium.

So the people of North Sydney will certainly have an intimate part in the marathon run. Most importantly, the marathon runners will be able to get a very good sighting not just of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the magnificent harbour, and not just of the beautiful vistas around the harbour on the way to Homebush Bay; they will also get a fantastic view of one of God's electorates—North Sydney. That is very important. And on that occasion I think we will be able to convince the state government, notwithstanding the fact that they have severe budgetary problems, to lift the tolls so that the marathon runners will not have to pay.

As my colleague John Fahey, the Minister for Finance, said in 1993 when he was Premier of New South Wales, the Sydney Olympics and the Paralympics offer the opportunity to inspire a generation. The Sydney games will give all Australians an unprecedented opportunity to show the world the diversity, skills and natural beauty of our unique nation. This legislation is further evidence of the government's commitment to make the Sydney games a success. As law‐makers we have a responsibility—indeed, an obligation—to do all that we can to ensure that the Sydney 2000 games are carried out in a highly professional and fiscally responsible manner. This legislation is just one way in which we can fulfil that obligation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to rise to support the Sydney 2000 (Indicia and Images) Protection Amendment Bill. Unlike the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), who is going to have the whole marathon team running through his electorate, the Northern Territory will be lucky if we got a torchbearer moving through the territory at some particular time.
—You can re‐route it through the Northern Territory.

—Yes. I think Darwin and Alice Springs is a bit far out of the way! This bill introduces some amendments to the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Act, passed by this parliament in 1996. Specifically, the purpose of the bill is to introduce a licensing regime that restricts the use of several key words, phrases and images, specifically with the Sydney 2000 Olympics. It allows for injunctions to prevent breaches of the licensing requirements. It compensates those sponsors who may face damage from an unlicensed rival. The bill would give the Australian Customs Service the power to seize goods that they suspect contravene the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is suspected that the cost of hosting the Olympic Games in 2000 will be between $2 billion and $3 billion. The figures are obtained from the second reading speech of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games (Mr Warwick Smith). He said it would cost in excess of $2 billion.

The parliamentary digest figures say that it is between $2 billion and $3 billion. Television rights have been sold for record amounts and the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments will provide limited funds to cover costs, but the commercial sponsorship is required to provide a large portion of the remaining costs.

Corporate sponsorship will be the second largest source of revenue from the Games and therefore it is important that the sponsors are given exclusive rights and that they get value for their money. In fact, the host country is obliged under the contract between the host city, Sydney, and the Australian Olympic Committee and SOCOG to provide adequate protection for sponsors.

Since the bill was introduced by the honourable minister, Madam Deputy Chair, I have received a brochure from the Sydney SOCOG which lists the major international and Australian sponsors. It is a very impressive list. As mentioned by the member for North Sydney, the Sydney 2000 Games is going to be probably the most prestigious games that will be held in the Southern Hemisphere for many a long time.

However, the highest level of sponsorship in the team millennium Olympic partners includes global sponsors Coca‐Cola, IBM, Visa, Fuji Xerox, UPS, Kodak, McDonald's, Panasonic and Time with international rights. The team millennium Olympic partners also include an impressive list of Australia's leading companies such as Westpac, Telstra, BHP, Westfield, AMP, Ansett Australia, Energy Australia and Swatch with national rights as well. No doubt, as we get closer to the year 2000, other smaller organisations will come on stream in terms of providing sponsorship.

The bill involved much consultation with interested parties, including Games organisers and, more importantly, retailers. It was decided that a register of licensees would be readily available to business for verification of merchandise and therein not disadvantage retailers.

BREAK.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney mentioned the fact that if Shane Warne were to participate in the decathlon he might be able to wear his Nike earring. At the same time I can remember watching a television program recently which said that some large organisations which are not official sponsors of particular games or other sporting activities get well‐paid athletes who are very well known and put them in their sporting apparel, which sometimes does not contravene the spirit of the franchise.

That may be legal or illegal, and perhaps the minister might be able to tell me at some later date. If I remember rightly, Reebok were the major sponsors for running shoes for the last games. But one of the competitors wore gold Nike running shoes. Obviously it would have upset the Reebok company, because they had paid an enormous amount of money for an exclusive franchise for their product, to have a rival company gazump them by having one of the world's best athletes wear its shoes.
Hopefully, this bill will stop ambush marketing. In March1995, the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, at page 22 of its report, defined ambush marketing as:

The unauthorised association by the business by their names, brands, products or services with a sports event or competition through any one or more of a wide range of marketing activities; `unauthorised' in the sense that the controller of the commercial rights in such events, usually the relevant governing body, has neither sanctioned or licensed the association itself or through its commercial agents.

In other words, corporations would be able to use the Sydney Olympic symbols for their own commercial gain, without paying a fee. If this were a frequent occurrence, SOCOG would lose money, and sponsors, who have paid large licence fees, often as high as $40 million, would see their previously guaranteed exclusive rights eroded.

To protect official sponsors from this sort of advertising, the bill sets up a regime which limits the use of key words for commercial purposes. These include the millennium games, Sydney Games, Sydney 2000—or any combination of the words games and 2000—Olympiad, Olympic, share the spirit, summer games, team millennium, any combination of the words 24th and Olympic or games, use of the word Olympian or Olympic with gold, silver or bronze, and the use of any visual or oral representation representing a connection with the Olympic or Paralympic Games.

However, the legislation does allow for some exemptions. Businesses already using prescribed words, such as Olympic Airways, can continue to use them so long as they do not try to infer a formal relationship with the Olympic Games. The exemptions also include the reporting of factual information relating to the Olympics, as in the use of news stories or tour operators. Sporting bodies are also given some leeway so that they can effectively promote their teams and athletes in order to raise awareness and to fundraise. It is recommended that these bodies negotiate a memorandum of understanding with the games organisers in order to safeguard their activities.

The Olympic Games to be held in Australia in the year 2000 will be an opportunity to showcase our nation to the world. It is therefore important that SOCOG is able to raise the funds necessary to run the Olympics well. As the bill is an important way of protecting the financial integrity of the games and involves minimal Commonwealth financial outlays, I have pleasure in commending the bill to the House.

Finally, I think the whole Australian community should be gearing up for the year 2000. When we in the Northern Territory hear of the number of visitors expected to visit Australia for the 2000 games, we are very keen to make sure that everything works out well in the lead up to the games and, of course, the games. Visitors coming to Australia need to feel that the organisers have the capacity to provide the transport facilities, the accommodation facilities, and all the other technical facilities that are required in the running of the games.

Obviously, people in Western Australia, South Australia, the Northern Territory, and other parts of Australia are hopeful that once the games are over there will be an influx of visitors to their state or territory. That will have a benefit for tourism, which is very important. We can take note of what happened after the Commonwealth Games in 1988. It is reported that after the people had visited Brisbane there was a great influx of visitors to the southern capitals of Australia. Obviously that had the benefit of the revenue derived from it. I congratulate the ministers involved in the passing of this legislation and wish them well for the year 2000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —In briefly summing up, I thank all those that have contributed. Firstly, Mr Martin, the member for Cunningham, on behalf of the opposition has indicated that they will support this amendment to the bill which we passed in the parliament back on 28 June. We thank him for that support.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Abbott, the member for Warringah, indicated some concerns about the movement of people visiting Sydney in the year 2000 for the games. He should be assured that there is extensive activity taking place in New South Wales to develop a road system and a rail system, and so on, to meet the expected arrivals. A lot of work is being done also with regard to Sydney airport but it is not appropriate to deal with all of that here at the present.

PARA.TAB: The member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton) indicated that he had a personal interest in the graphic design development for the mascots for the games and wondered about the extension of the protection to cover the mascots usage beyond the cut‐off date in the legislation, 31 December in the year 2000. The mascots are protected under the definitional sections of the principal act in section 9, but SOCOG also could register the mascots as trademarks to protect them for a further 10 years beyond the games. I think that that is a point that he perhaps could take back. I would certainly raise that with SOCOG and Minister Knight who will be in Canberra next week.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Dickson, Mr Tony Smith, did a detailed overview of the benefit of the games to the nation and I think all members appreciate that fact.

Mr Hockey, the member for North Sydney, gave a detailed and well‐researched coverage of the issue of sponsorship; this amendment to the principal bill is primarily about protecting the activities of sponsors who register under the principal act. The cost of the games has been said by many speakers to be somewhere in the vicinity of $2 billion to $3 billion. The licensing fees alone, which this bill primarily seeks to protect, are of the order of $700 million. Personally, I think it will be worth considerably more than that, but here we have the Commonwealth parliament in a bipartisan way taking a very positive step to provide the protection to underpin the flow of funds required to meet the $2 billion to $3 billion expected costs to sponsor what will be undoubtedly the pre‐eminent Olympic Games in our lifetime, occurring as they do on the turn of the century. The millennium games will, in fact, be a wonderful showcase for Australia, so it is incumbent on all of us to do everything we can to make sure that we do it well.

The other matters that I wanted to briefly raise were touched on by several of the speakers, and indeed Mr Dondas, the member for the Northern Territory, raised the issue of the benefit to the rest of the nation. It is not just, of course, the Sydney Games. The benefit to the rest of the nation is pre‐eminent in all of our minds as is ensuring successful visits prior to the games by overseas teams—I addressed that in question time yesterday. Follow‐up visits are also going to be particularly important.

One of the activities engaged in by the New South Wales government and by this government is the development of an Olympic business round table. Detailed discussions and strategies are being developed to make sure that the private sector is able to secure longer‐term economic dividends from the games in the form of more jobs through increased overseas investment and trade and international tourism. Detailed discussions with Austrade and the Australian Tourism Commission and other Commonwealth departments, together with the Olympic business round table and the New South Wales government have been undertaken for some time and we expect, as we go a little closer to the games, that there will be a more public manifestation of those discussions.

The Commonwealth has already contributed $150 million to the facilities for the games. We have undertaken to fund up to $25 million to stage the Paralympic Games. We have provided $25 million for the Sydney showground to be relocated. We are passing this legislation, which in its minimum form will underpin a value to the games organisers of some $700 million. We have established two ministerial committees, both of which I chair; one relates to taking an overview about passenger facilitation, Sydney airport, telecommunications, customs, meteorology and so on. We have some 35 Commonwealth departments and agencies involved in a coordinated approach working with SOCOG and New South Wales to ensure that every contingency that we can possibly think of is covered.

The other key committee is a committee of the National Security Committee which I chair on security matters. That committee brings together all the security agencies of the Commonwealth to work with New South Wales police, SOCOG and international agencies in ensuring that every step is taken to make sure that, during the course of the games, we have covered every potential eventuality that might occur in that particularly difficult area.

The other area for which I am responsible relates to the funding of the athletes so that they can excel in the 2000 games. We hope Australian athletes will be able to do as well as they did in Atlanta, which was the best ever Australian performance at an Olympic Games. We have somewhere in the vicinity of $135 million per year under the Olympic athlete program. There will be about $360 million that will be provided by the Commonwealth government for the preparation of our athletes for the year 2000; that is a very significant amount. So, all in all, the government is well progressed down the path of ensuring that the Sydney 2000 games are able to be achieved to the satisfaction of all.

This amendment follows a great deal of consultation. It builds on the principal act. It relates, as other speakers have said, to the protection of licence holders and provides a speedier method by which prosecution can take place to ensure that protection becomes a reality. It is something that is absolutely essential to the financial wellbeing of the games. I think it was the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) who referred to the difficulties in Montreal; that they will still be paying their games off in the year 2005. We want to avoid that prospect in this country in the year 2000.

I am therefore particularly pleased that all sides of the parliament have been able to join with the government in ensuring that this legislation is put into effect. I thank all speakers for their very useful and helpful contributions on an important national issue that will capture the attention of all of us, certainly in the year 2000, if not as we get closer to it.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROAD TRANSPORT REFORM (DANGEROUS GOODS) AMENDMENT BILL 1996 Cognate bill: ROAD TRANSPORT REFORM (HEAVY VEHICLES REGISTRATION) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation amends the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act and enacts the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Act. The Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Bill is essentially technical and non‐controversial. It relates to clarifying the regulation making power under the existing legislation, which was passed by the parliament in 1995, and various other technical amendments, which I will not address in my contribution to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill is essentially designed to create a framework for uniform national regulation of road transport by heavy vehicles which is a product of a process established by the former Labor government, through the National Road Transport Commission, to produce uniform regulatory structures regarding road transport throughout Australia. What the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill does is establish a regulatory framework through which we will achieve uniform regulation of heavy vehicle transport throughout Australia. It does not go to a huge amount of detail because essentially, as is the case with most legislation of this nature, the regulatory processes will be through the making of regulations, rather than provisions in the act of parliament itself. It is supported by the opposition, as is the amendment to the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act.

I will comment, briefly, primarily on the second of the two pieces of legislation, the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996. It is part of a broader picture which, as I indicated, was introduced by the Keating government in 1992 with the agreement of all states and territories and the support of the then opposition. The opposition strongly supports the continuation of the reform process that was established at that time and has been working reasonably well till now.

It is a fairly difficult process, because the nature of road transport is by no means uniform across the country. The sorts of circumstances that prevail, for example, in rural Western Australia with respect to road transport are very different from circumstances that prevail in metropolitan Sydney and metropolitan Melbourne. So in some respects there are pressures for differences which have had to be worked through in the process of negotiation and discussion between the states and territories and the Commonwealth, through the NRTC process.

My observation to date has been that this process has worked pretty well. All the stakeholders remain committed to it and, in my understanding, fairly satisfied with the progress that is being made. I took the opportunity to be briefed by the NRTC people some time ago, and I have been impressed with the work that is being done and the progress that is being made. This piece of legislation is an important step forward in developing that process of uniform national regulation.

The road transport industry is a very difficult industry to regulate. There is plenty of history to indicate to us that simply legislating, simply putting regulations on the books, is not necessarily going to achieve the outcome that we as parliamentarians might desire. It is not easy to ensure that rules and regulations are being adhered to when you have got a large number of heavy vehicles using the roads at all times of the day, right across the country. Policing is always going to be difficult in this area.

There are many smaller operators in the industry. It has been a pattern in recent times that we have had an increasing number of owner‐drivers or small companies emerging who in some instances have been breaking regulations with relative impunity. It is a serious problem, particularly with respect to issues such as driver hours. Many long haul journeys are necessary because of Australia's size, particularly along the east coast between Brisbane and Melbourne, and across the Nullarbor, and it is very difficult to ensure that drivers are driving only the maximum hours—which until now have varied from state to state, ranging from 11 hours to 14 hours of non-stop driving. It is very difficult to ensure that you can police this properly. The consequence of drivers breaking these laws is potentially loss of life on the road, fatigue, accidents and serious road trauma.

Unfortunately, while you have intense competition, while you have ever mounting competitive pressures on businesses to diminish their costs, which often include substantial transport costs, then you are going to end up in a situation where the pressure on price for transport is reflected in people breaking the rules. That is precisely what is happening. It is difficult to estimate how much, but, as a very good indicator of how serious the problem is, the three major operators in this industry in the past—Mayne Nickless, Brambles and TNT—all in some form or other have exited or have been in the process of exiting from the general road transport industry over the past year or two. The reason is that their capacity to make reasonable profits out of their operations in this industry and at the same time comply with the law has more or less been obliterated by competition from smaller operators. In some instances the competitive advantage of those smaller operators is not that they are more efficient, not that they are better at what they are doing, not that they are doing it more quickly—legitimately—but that they are breaking the rules. They are forcing drivers to drive ridiculous hours—

TALK.START.PARA: —And they are not doing proper maintenance.

—As my colleague indicates, they are not properly maintaining their vehicles, not maintaining them in a safe way; they are breaking a whole range of regulations that are there ultimately to protect people who use the roads—not only people who are driving the trucks but also other road users. That is a serious problem and I certainly do not believe that simply passing legislation is going to resolve these issues. It is something that requires a great deal more.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Road Transport Commission has come up with a proposal called `fatigue management', which is a slightly more sophisticated strategy for dealing with the issue of driver hours. I am fairly sceptical about the prospects for this approach because, amongst other things, it actually lengthens, technically, the number of driver hours that can be driven legally. This is under a regime where the drivers are supposed to manage the amount of time they are actually in the saddle, so to speak, and it is supposed to ensure that they have breaks.

Time will tell how effective this approach is going to be. As I said, I have some substantial reservations about it, but I am prepared to accept that the National Road Transport Commission needs to make some attempt to tackle these issues. I would actually prefer to maintain a fairly strict regime. The old logbook system clearly works more in the breach than successfully in observance. There are other options, some of which have some difficulties. Electronic monitoring is one of the possibilities that is opening up but there are some difficulties with that. Clearly, it is a controversial prospect, but we need to be putting a lot of effort into this.

I commend the government for continuing the process with the National Road Transport Commission. This piece of legislation is one of the steps and I urge the government to pay particular heed to these issues of safety, hours and maintenance, which are all part of the total picture in this industry.

Unfortunately, we are seeing a pattern of exploitation in the road transport industry. It has been there for a long time and it is gradually mounting. We have a situation where owner drivers no longer have any form of industrial regulatory protection. An attempt was made to put that in the industrial relations legislation of the former government; it was effectively neutered by the High Court, and it is has now been removed in the new workplace relations act.

Again, it is something that is difficult to regulate, but it is a key component of the problems in this industry. Many owner drivers are very vulnerable to being exploited because ultimately they have to get their vehicles on the road and they have to get some revenue coming through no matter what the circumstances. So it is extremely important that we pay some attention to some form of industry protection for owner drivers as well.

The key issue, and the underlying theme pertinent to the question of registration of heavy vehicles, is that of fair competition in the industry; not only fair competition within road transport but also fair competition between road transport and other modes. There is a lot of inflammatory and inaccurate material around about the contribution that the heavy road transport industry makes to road trauma. In fact, 70 per cent of accidents involving large trucks are caused by drivers other than the driver of the truck.

It is an important statistic that we need to note. The sort of thing that you sometimes see on tabloid current affairs shows about drivers high on drugs and all these killer trucks on the roads is often grossly exaggerated. We need to concentrate on the facts and not so much on the tabloid presentation.

There is a problem and, as a parliament, we need to make sure that we steadily diminish that problem. The difficulty we have at the moment is that it seems to be increasing because of the competitive pressures which mean that there are lots of people out there—lots of small companies and owner drivers—who are under ever increasing pressure to bend or break the rules.

The end result is unfair competition, which impacts adversely on those who do adhere to the rules, including the larger companies. At the same time, it potentially places lives at risk because there are drivers on the roads who have been driving for ridiculously long periods of time and who are almost by definition going to be a safety risk. There are vehicles that have not been properly maintained and a range of other problems. So I urge the government to treat this issue very seriously and to put as much support as it can behind the NRTC to ensure that the entire road transport industry—a highly competitive, productive and efficient industry—operates on the basis of fair competition and a fair deal for its drivers.

I was disappointed to see that the government has chosen to intervene in the recent wages case with respect to the Transport Workers Union and the Australian Road Transport Industry Organisation. The government has put the view that this deal is about trying to enforce higher wage costs on a lot of smaller operators in the industry, thereby changing the balance in the competitive arrangements between them and the big operators.

I take a different view. My view is that most truck drivers do not get paid very much to start with and, of all the workers around the place, they would be pretty high on the list of people who should be paid more. One of the reasons they are not is because of the problems of regulating the industry and the fact that, at the bottom end, there is this intense and often illegal and unfair competition which imposes enormous downward pressures on their wages. Therefore, it is important to ensure, not only that there is proper regulation in the industry to minimise that, but also that there is some sort of fair wages outcome. That is reason why the government was wrong to intervene in that case. Truck drivers should get paid a reasonable wage for what is ultimately a difficult job, a skilled job and a job that has lots of disadvantages—the long hours, the time away from families and the like. That should be done by ensuring that that job has actually got a decent rate of pay.

I have a final comment to make in that context. This is not meant by way of any criticism, either of the current government or the former government, but merely as a suggestion to which I hope the government will give some consideration. In tackling this set of issues in the future, one of the things that we have got to start focusing on is rewarding the good firms, because there are plenty of small and medium sized road transport operators out there who do the right thing. In spite of the fact that it hurts them, and in spite of the fact that they run the risk of losing contracts to the competitor around the corner who does not do the right thing, they do it. They ensure that their drivers have proper breaks, are not driving 20 hours at a stretch or 36 hours with only a three‐ or six‐hour break in the middle. They do the right thing, they ensure that their maintenance is adequate and that they do not cut corners.

One of the things that we as a parliament and as legislators need to do is to build structures which guarantee that, in some form or other, those who do the right thing actually get rewarded through the processes of regulation. I do not have any specific suggestions as yet, but it is something that I intend paying some attention to. I urge those on the government side to think about that because it may be one way of starting to diminish some of these problems. It would create some incentives for these companies and these operators to abide by the law, and not put them in a position where the only incentive is to be a good corporate citizen and where the negatives they face are those of losing contracts, losing work. We need to add something else to the equation that will ensure that we have a much higher degree of compliance with the existing regulations and any future regulations than we do at the moment. As I indicated, the opposition supports both pieces of legislation that are before this chamber at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the shadow minister is supporting the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996. I have appreciated his sensible remarks and considered views on a number of issues. I would take issue on his position in relation to the 11 per cent claim by the TWU.
—Surprise!

—I note, however, his recognition of the very competitive forces that operate, below the bigger trucking companies, within those smaller operators who go out to seek contract rates that are almost the bare bones of making profitability. Both he and I would be aware of that very difficult set of conditions where the smaller companies subcontract and tend to break the regulations. I agree with him about that competitive nature of the industry. I note, however, the very strong and entrenched position of the TWU and its relationship with some of the bigger trucking companies about which I will debate with him at another time. So I am pleased to hear the support of the shadow minister and the initiative of the former government on this very important national issue.

BREAK.PARA: This goes back to arguments that some of us have been close to in terms of section 92, that road transport operators could use some state jurisdictions to register their operations and achieve some savings and travel across state boundaries because of section 92. The licensing of particular interstate truck drivers, again, was a matter of concern over many years where, say, truck drivers in Victoria who travelled to New South Wales and Queensland were not subject to those state regulations.

Before the shadow minister leaves I would just like to compliment the former government on the standard national gauge because in similar terms to this bill, the standard gauge was achieved during the time of the former government, having been on the books since 1927. I place on the record my very strong support for the completion of that gauge. That is compatible with the legislation we now have before the House.

To look at some of the details of the bill, this is one of the vital, but probably not well known, micro‐economic reforms of recent years, moving to national uniform and consistent regulations for road transport. In Australia we are well aware of our major shortcomings. One of the features of our history since federation has been the differing rules and regulations applying from state to state. That is all too evident to people who have an interest in these matters. States have fought over rail gauges and regulation for their road industries. There are also the arguments about daylight saving between Queensland and the southern states. Hopefully, here in the federal parliament we can get consensus in this road transport area that might lead to a more sensible, rational approach.

The wider community may have some understanding of the issue if they consider the differences in general road rules and different rules applying to driver's licences in different states and territories. Traditionally, Victoria has had a different right of way rule for turning at intersections. The ACT has different rules for obtaining a driver's licence which allows a full licence to be obtained at the age of 17. We even have different blood alcohol limits across the states, especially for those with provisional licences, which seems a strange set of circumstances. The same inconsistencies have affected the commercial transport sector.

These two bills are important steps down the path of ensuring a national uniform system of regulation for road transport. They will bring about administrative savings to governments and efficiency benefits to the industry. The first step down the path to uniform national road transport regulations occurred in 1991 at the Special Premiers Conference, a part of the new federalism concept initiated by Prime Minister Hawke and a forerunner to the COAG process.

It was following that conference that the National Road Transport Commission was established. It was overseen by ministerial council to implement the nationally uniform or consistent road regulations across Australia. The NRTC is in the process of developing the new national road transport law through six modules. These modules include road transport charges, vehicle and traffic driver licences as well as compliance and enforcement. All of these issues are matters which this parliament and state parliaments have grappled with for many years.

The two areas that are dealt with by these two bills are the transport of dangerous goods and the issue of registration for heavy vehicles. In each case the proposed regulation and legislation undergoes a thorough process of scrutiny by industry players, enforcement agencies in each state and territory, and governments in each jurisdiction. All such proposals ultimately must be accepted by the ministerial council before they are enacted into complementary legislation at the Commonwealth, state and territory level.

The most recent annual report of the National Road Transport Commission reports that the 1995‐96 year saw these national transport reforms really taking effect. I am delighted to see that progress at long last is being made. Thus, we are moving from the planning, argument and debating stage to the implementation stage in several areas, and the reform process is beginning to bear fruit.

We have already seen in 1996 the adoption of uniform national registration charges for heavy vehicles in all Australian jurisdictions. I well recall the arguments on that in terms of livestock transport, the definition of heavy vehicles, and the intransigence of New South Wales in conforming with some of the desires of the former Labor government to try to get a national position.

The two bills before the House will help us move down the path towards uniform road transport laws in areas of heavy vehicle registration and the transport of dangerous goods. The dangerous goods part of it seems innocuous enough but, in my view, that is a helpful precedent because everyone in every state can agree that dangerous goods transport is a problem. In Victoria we have the argument about Point Lillias and Coode Island in terms of transport of dangerous goods, so it is a particular issue near and around my electorate.

The legislation to control the transport of dangerous goods in Australia dates back to the turn of the century when most Australian states legislated to control the transport of explosives on the basis of the United Kingdom's Explosives Act 1875. Later this century, most states legislated to control the transport of flammable liquids. It was not until 1973 that the first moves were taken towards developing a nationally consistent framework for regulating the transport of dangerous goods. This goal was partially realised in 1980 with the establishment of the Australian Code for the Transport of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail.

1994 saw the passage of the original Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act, which sets out the broad legislative framework for establishing uniform laws across Australia. I recall some of the debate on that act and, as I say, that sets a precedent for some of these other nationally uniform regulations. This was followed by the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Regulations and now the amendment bill is before the House, which will ensure that the regulations can be implemented in practical terms.

These reforms are designed to enhance the safety of transporting dangerous goods, to improve the national consistency of these laws and to ensure improved compliance and enforceability. They will also improve the complementarity of the rules for other modes of transport, as well as international practice. The regulations set down uniform requirements for the classification and packaging of dangerous goods, placarding and marking of vehicles and containers which carry such goods in bulk, transport documentation, procedures for transport and transfer of dangerous goods, and emergency provisions. There will also be a uniform system for licensing drivers of vehicles carrying dangerous goods in bulk. The regulation will go some way in clarifying the roles, duties and responsibilities of those involved in the transport of dangerous goods. Most importantly, we will have a system of regulation for transport of hazardous substances which is recognised all over Australia, wiping out the expense and complication associated with numerous state and territory laws.
