I do not think anyone on either side of the House could complain about those sets of objectives and I am hopeful that they will be implemented in a practical form at the state level. Citizens will feel more comfortable when they see some of these very large vehicles carrying dangerous goods, knowing that if an accident occurs, action will be taken, people will understand what to do and fire prevention authorities will have sufficient information to handle such an unfortunate happening.

In relation to the heavy vehicle registration, which has always been a bone of contention with the transport companies and state government, the same objective applies to the rules governing the registration of heavy vehicles. Heavy vehicle registration is yet another aspect of road transport to be affected by differing rules in different jurisdictions, be they state or federal. The National Road Transport Commission aims to ensure that the rules governing requirements for registration vehicles over 4½ tonnes are uniform and consistent between all states and territories. The Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicle Registration) Bill will set out the broad legislative framework for this important initiative.

The national scheme will mean that, for the first time in Australia's history, we will have uniform requirements for new registrations, re‐registrations, renewals, registration transfer, interstate conversion, suspension and cancellation, and conditional registration. Some of the main features of the proposed scheme include the availability of three, six and 12 months or part‐year registration. I think, again, all these are fairly straightforward and commonsense recommendations.

I just note the long debate and discussion that has been going on as usual between the Commonwealth, who had a desire to make an Australia‐wide position, and some of the states, who always complained that they had special conditions. They would not budge in making what I see as a very sensible piece of legislation.

The new concept of a registered operator as opposed to the traditional term `vehicle owner' as a name in which a vehicle is registered and the requirement that vehicles must be registered in the same state as their principal base of operations helps to identify and curb some of the schemes that some of the smaller companies were using to beat taxation systems and some of the registrations that were historically operating under the section 92 regime.

The cost of implementing the scheme will not be met by the Commonwealth but by the states and territories. The NRTC estimates that the establishment cost of the scheme to the state vehicle registration authorities will be $12.4 million overall. However, the streamlined and efficient uniform registration system will provide benefits of around $10 million to those same authorities overall. Vehicle operators themselves are expected to gain around $14 million dollars in benefits, and I am quite confident that they will be very pleased, once the scheme settles down, with the paper warfare and the general administrative structures that will be in place, and with the fact that they will not be dealing with, in some cases, four or five individual state governments. Enforcement agencies are estimated to benefit by $1.5 million. The introduction of a uniform scheme for both the registration of heavy vehicles and the transporting of dangerous goods will bring about administrative savings as well as efficiency gains to the vitally important road transport industry. These are two early achievements in the development of uniform national road laws—an important micro‐economic reform in the road transport sector.

Some of the other projects which the NRTC is also working on in order to develop uniform and consistent rules will hopefully bear fruit in the next few years. The commission has looked into the issue of truck driving hours, an issue which has been given considerable attention to date. I note that the shadow minister mentioned that in his contribution to the Committee. Presently, no two Australian jurisdictions have the same driving hour limits for truck drivers, thus creating significant difficulties for interstate operators to comply with the law, even if they had a genuine desire to do so. The commission is working towards a national system which could strike an appropriate balance between road safety, efficiency and current industry practice.

Meanwhile, the commission has initiated a training course for fatigue management in the trucking industry. Again, the shadow minister mentioned the considerable problem of the long hours worked by truck drivers. It is something that the management of the trucking companies, governments and individual Australians have been grappling with. I do appreciate some of the competitive pressures; on the other hand, we do need some form of regulation to ensure the safety of those operators, who sometimes drive 12‐ or 14‐hour stretches, thus endangering both their own lives and the lives of other Australians in passenger vehicles. Anyone who has been on the Hume Highway would be very aware of the hazards that everyone faces.

TALK.START.PARA: —And are terrified by.

—And are terrified, as the honourable member interjects; and I agree with him. If some drivers are fatigued by doing a couple more trips than they should have done, that certainly endangers those big trucking rigs worth a quarter of a million dollars and more and also the individual Australians who can get caught up in a major accident. Meanwhile, the development of a nationally recognised log book is something which is always a bone of contention with truck drivers, in terms of whether they fill the log book in correctly, whether it can be challenged and whether it is a meaningful document through which to try to control the hours worked by truck drivers.

BREAK.PARA: The other area to which the NRTC has directed its attention is the review of the mass limits which regulate the carrying capacity of trucking operators. Again, there is an argument as to whether trucks are overloaded. It is estimated, according to the NRTC annual report, that even a small increase in mass limits can generate big economic savings—as much as $1 billion over fifteen years.

Thus, the work of the National Road Transport Commission is far from over. The Chairman, John Hurlstone, and the Chief Executive, David O'Sullivan, will continue the long hard grind towards national standards and uniform laws for Australia's road transport sector. No one should underestimate the importance of these reforms. Just as we now transport containers from Brisbane to Perth on the national gauge line, which I mentioned, we can also truck goods by road with uniform road charges, registration requirements and rules for transport of dangerous goods throughout the whole nation.

It is to be hoped that at some time in the near future Australians will have a national system of drivers' licences, road rules and road safety laws. This legislation could be a forerunner, if the federal parliament could persuade the states to adopt a national system in this area, so that we have a sensible national view of these regulations. As with gun laws, daylight saving hours and rail gauges, there seem to be significant benefits in having a national system which is consistent between the various state jurisdictions and known by all operators and all companies around Australia.

I hope that the trend and the thrust of this legislation will help this parliament, in a bipartisan manner, develop further legislation which will bring about a more sensible approach to both the road transport system and the rail transport system. I have had a long and enduring interest in getting some uniform, sensible approaches to a standard gauge, one‐track Australia. I hope that the state rail authorities might have a sensible view as to how we can integrate a national rail system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except in Victoria and New South Wales.

—We will have that debate at another time. It is my hope that over the next two parliaments we will see the standard gauge. This piece of legislation will bring about a change of attitude in the legislators and in the population at large. I commend the legislation to the House and thank the opposition for its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this cognate debate dealing with Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996. As the shadow minister, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), has indicated, the opposition supports these bills. Indeed, why shouldn't we? They are just technical details and amendments to legislation that we brought in when we were in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, in this chamber, one of the members from the government, I think it was the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) in his contribution, said that people out there in voter land do not realise how much bipartisan legislation goes through this chamber, more so in this chamber than in the other place. It is true; a lot of legislation does go through here and this is a good example. I do not think there is disagreement between the government and the opposition on this.

The heavy vehicles registration bill establishes a framework for a national registration scheme for heavy vehicles throughout Australia and provides uniform arrangements for initial registration, renewal, transfer, suspension and cancellation of registration, and the issue and clearance of vehicle defect notices.

As I understand it, the legislative framework will apply within the ACT and the Jervis Bay territory. Hopefully, as the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) said, it will be adopted by all of the states. More and more, especially with respect to transport matters, we have to look at having uniform legislation across all of the states.

The dangerous goods amendment bill makes a number of fairly technical drafting amendments to the bill passed when the Labor Party was in government. They are to be welcomed as they will form part of a system of nationally consistent road transport laws, which were first proposed as long ago as the Heads of Government Meeting in 1991.

As a nation we inhabit one of the most expansive land masses on earth. Our population is spread around the coastline and the nation is crisscrossed by roads. It is not the easiest task in the world to get agreement between the various states and territories of this country. With this legislation, there has been an amount of agreement and, as I said before, it is no easy task. There are people who argue that their state should be excluded, and someone mentioned the gun laws. We hear various arguments as to why various states should be excluded from one piece of legislation or another but, unless we have all‐inclusive national legislation, the whole thing will not work.

We, as a nation, rely more than most others on the road and rail network to transport goods and, indeed, to transport ourselves. The efficiency of our road transport system has been undermined in the past by inconsistent and contradictory road regulations. Many people have used the example of a truck going from Perth or Geraldton or somewhere else in Western Australia across to Brisbane, and have spoken about the various state laws that it would encounter and the regulations that would have to be complied with on that journey, instead of there being one set of laws and regulations to cover the whole journey. Each state and territory has had its own interpretation of the laws. In some states this has caused a delay in the economic development and has also involved many people in considerable cost.

These bills are an example of legislators and policy makers realising that Australia, with a diverse federation of six states and two territories, is in fact one nation. In 1992 the National Road Transport Commission was established, following agreement by the Commonwealth, states and territories to develop nationally uniform or consistent regulations relating to the construction and use of heavy vehicles. These bills establish the framework for the implementation of uniform legislation. It has been achieved by cooperation and consultation—as I said before, not always easy when you are dealing with diverse states and territories.

We are, though, a federation. Over the years people have often spoken about states rights, but surely in a nation as large and diverse as this we should, as legislators and policy makers, ensure that if nothing else our transport system is integrated and uniform according to a national standard. Such is the case with this legislation.

Not many of us know what is transported by road. The previous speaker referred to the Hume Highway. I drive along the Hume Highway every week to and from Canberra and it is true that there are many, many trucks on it. There is an argument, as people have said, that a lot of what is transported by road should really be transported by rail, but I have always held that point of view. Nevertheless, so much is transported by road today. When I am driving along at my leisurely 90 or maybe up to 100 kilometres an hour I see trucks going past me doing 120 or 130—just going past me and going into the distance. Often the tarpaulins are flapping in the wind. I often wonder what dangerous goods are being transported in these trucks and what would happen if, as often happens, there were an accident or, as sometimes happens, something fell off one of these trucks.

I must say that when I go past Goulburn it is always with a sense of relief that I turn off the Hume Highway onto the Federal Highway, because there are not as many trucks on that road and I do not have to be as concerned with what they are carrying and what would have happened if something had fallen off a truck. Often we do not know what these trucks are carrying until an accident occurs and someone is killed or injured or there is a spillage of chemicals or a fire. When there is a spill we read in the media the next day about the big clean‐up and how many people from the various towns along the highway had to be evacuated. Indeed, often it is only when the media gets hold of it that we learn of some of the dangerous goods that are being transported. We should be more aware of what is being transported—not only, incidentally, goods going by road but some of the chemicals that go round our coastline by ship as well. If there are ever leakages and spills off the coast they are going to have disastrous impacts.

BREAK.PARA: There is now a national uniformity and the vehicle operators are going to be subject to consistent regulations. No longer will there be a need or requirement for different licences or registrations to be held by vehicle operators travelling between different states and territories, transporting these goods throughout Australia.

This legislation will also provide authorised officers with a greater range of powers to ensure industry compliance with the new regulations. All state and territory governments, and industry representatives, agree that the regulations will improve the administration and transportation of dangerous goods. The defence establishment has also supported moves to uniform national road laws and regulations, and aims to meet all of the rules and regulations unless special circumstances dictate otherwise. One would have to wonder what those special circumstances might be.

Under the provision of the Defence Act 1903, Defence has scope to operate outside the rules and regulations of the states and territories under certain circumstances, such as when conducting operations or training. Discussions are well advanced between the Department of Defence and the Office of Road Safety to clarify further these remaining issues. The goal will be to fashion a Commonwealth position on the transportation of dangerous goods by Defence.

I am pleased to see that this legislation will not create inconsistencies of its own regarding the rail transportation of dangerous goods. The legislation ensures that rail transport is not excluded from the Australian dangerous goods code or the Australian explosives code. The federal Office of Road Safety has taken the initiative to ensure that rail requirements are written into the ADG code in a manner which will ensure complete consistency with road regulations.

No matter what legislation is introduced, however, nothing will ensure that dangerous goods are transported more safely and efficiently than roads that are safe and in good condition. When there are the inevitable number of accidents over public holiday weekends—say, the Easter period or, as we have just seen, over the Christmas period—it is often said that driver fatigue, vehicle malfunction, alcohol, drugs and driving conditions are responsible for those deaths and injuries. A factor which is conveniently overlooked is the condition of the roads on which these people are killed or injured.

I believe that the previous government had a very good record of funding road construction and improvements under the national highway system. In the years that I have been a member of parliament, I have seen the improvements on the national highway I travel on as I come down to Canberra and the improvements further down with the Yass bypass. Indeed, even now I see improvements along Lake George as they are working there—not that we can take credit for the Lake George improvement, but we can take credit for the others. I also strongly hold the view that the state and territory governments have much to answer for in the expenditure of the road funding which the Commonwealth allocates to them each year.

The transportation of dangerous goods by road is hazardous at the best of times and I believe that this legislation will make that transportation throughout Australia much safer, more efficient and subject to uniform national rules and regulations—which is as it should be. I know that we often get complaints from truckies saying that their industry is overregulated. Knowing several truckies, I know they are always complaining about the fines, not always those on the big rigs on the national highways, but on timber trucks and the like. Some feel that they should be exempt from the law but, as the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) has highlighted, there is a lot of competition in this industry. It is not always the big national operators that break the law. It is often due to the very competitive nature of the cut‐throat industry they are in.

In my own area of the Illawarra there have been some horrendous accidents, especially when you are coming into Wollongong and coming down Mount Ousley or Bulli Pass where trucks have got away. Time and time again, when there is an examination of those trucks you find that there have been very serious defects. It is not always a matter of driver fatigue in that area. There was a case a couple of years ago where about six people were killed—a family wiped out—in a horrendous accident, and the driver had been forced by the owner to drive a vehicle that the driver knew had defects with the brakes and various other things.

So, while vehicles like that are on the roads we all use, I believe there should be very stringent conditions imposed, there should be regular inspections of the vehicles, and those who do not abide by the regulations should be hit with the book. I understand the very competitive nature of the industry, but there is no industry that needs to be so competitive that it is going to wipe out my family, your family or someone else's family.

The other point I make is that it is all very well to talk about the transportation of dangerous goods, we have got to do a little more policing about the dangerous risks some of these people—not all—who transport these dangerous goods take. They do for all sorts of reasons, such as the hours that they drive and the pressure that they are under. Frankly, I would not like to be behind the wheel of one of those huge rigs because I would not like to have that responsibility and, frankly, I would not do it for the pay that they get either. They have a very responsible job but they are sharing the roads of Australia with many other vehicles. Onerous as it may be, and I know how annoying it is to many in the trucking fraternity to have spot inspections and to have to comply with all these things, it is very necessary legislation which I support very much. As the shadow minister said, the opposition supports this legislation and I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend taking only a few moments of the committee's time this morning in rising to support the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996. Road transport is a very vital element to rural Australia, especially in the Northern Territory. It serves as an essential lifeline between our remote inland cities, particularly north of Alice Springs where there is no railway line. Hopefully, at some future stage, we might be able to rectify that. The road transport industry in the territory helps overcome the tyranny of distance that we face.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said just a few moments ago that it was very important that we attain some form of uniform legislation by way of regulation. I believe that is quite true. Most of our freight comes from the southern cities. If a vehicle is leaving Victoria it has got to go through South Australia. If it is coming out of New South Wales it has got to go through Queensland. There are very large distances and it would be quite silly if each state had its own border patrol with different regulations. That would obviously put an impost on the transport industry by holding them up and not letting them flow to their timetable—and some have got very busy timetables, as we have heard.

There were some concerns last year when heavy motor vehicle registration fees were increased to maintain this uniform legislation. In fact, some of the registration fees in the Northern Territory for the big rigs went from about $2,500 to, in some cases, $8,500 to $9,000 per rig. There was some concern that the additional registration fees may have put a higher cost on the freight rates for the consumer. I am pleased to say that those in the territory transport industry have probably been very mindful of that and the charges that have gone on to freight costs have, I think, been reasonable. They have not been considered to be unreasonable anyway.

The objectives of the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill are to introduce conformity and consistency to regulations governing road transport nationwide. The reforms will not only increase the safety and efficiency of our transport industry, but should also lower the administration costs. The process of reforming our road transport industry began in the early 1990s, and 1992 saw the establishment of the National Road Transport Commission with the aim of developing a set of uniform regulations for the use and construction of heavy vehicles.

I pick up another point that the honourable member for Throsby made. He said that he was pleased to be a part of the government of the time which introduced these new regulations for conformity and safety. But, at the same time, what is not generally known is that in some particular cases there was a lot of pressure put on the Northern Territory and Western Australia who were not happy with the particular proposal at that time.

In fact if my understanding is correct, at least in the Northern Territory, had the Northern Territory not conformed to that direction by the minister for transport that there should be uniform legislation then there may have been some fallback position that the minister may have taken in terms of maybe reduced funding levels for roads in the Northern Territory.

Nevertheless, having said that, we have now got the new regulations in force in the Northern Territory, registration fees have been increased and as I said, we do not believe that the higher freight costs that have been imposed on us by the industry in the Northern Territory have been unreasonable.

Many transport operators have found the system of different state and territory regulatory systems a burden on their business. The National Road Transport Commission called the system confusing and expensive to industry in its annual report of 1995‐96 and the administrative nightmare that the different regulations involved had a negative impact on the growth of the transport industry.

The heavy vehicle dangerous goods amendment bill is also about reform and uniformity of transport regulations. The bill is one step in the development of a national regulatory system for the transport of dangerous goods. It has three components. They are the broad framework provided by the act of 1995; the proposed regulations that will define the powers and the duties of those involved in transporting dangerous goods; and the sixth edition of the Australian Dangerous Goods Code, as mentioned by the honourable member for Throsby.

The public does have the right to feel safe and that a competent authority determines what goods are dangerous or not. This bill will provide for appropriate administration of these codes. Reflecting on the goods that are carried in the Northern Territory and South Australia, I note that the uranium oxide from Roxby Downs and Ranger mines certainly must be transported to a port. We are aware that there is no danger in the transporting of uranium oxide but the public perception is that if there were some kind of an accident there could be some problems associated with that spill.

Clause 2 repeals the current definition of the dangerous goods and the amendment broadens the definition. Other clauses of the bill relate to provisions of allowing further amendments by regulation. Obviously as we move towards uniform regulations it will be very time consuming to bring it back to the parliament every time there is going to be an amendment to the legislation. Part of the regulations provide the routes permissible for transporting dangerous goods. When one looks at the remote areas of Australia, I think the general community would be surprised at the size of the roadtrains and the type of cargo that they are carrying even taking into consideration the mining industry's activities in constructing new mines. In the case of wide cargoes, regulations are in place that insist that those people that are transporting wide loads or long loads must have an escort, forward and rear, of the convoy. At least it will make it a lot easier for those persons that are in the transport business to get permission to do that.

Licensing drivers and vehicles for the purpose of transporting dangerous goods is another regulation process. As regards appropriate and safe packaging, it was mentioned by somebody earlier today that some of the loads being carried by the operators can give some reason for concern. Packaging is very important, not only for the transport operators but also for those people in the warehouses where it is stored.

The bill also outlines procedures for documentation and checks by authorised officers. In fact there is a clause that relates to authorised officers, other than police officers, because each particular state does have its own road inspection system.

Obviously, it will make those officers' jobs a lot easier in checking the documentation because, as we have heard here earlier today, sometimes these drivers can be a bit tardy in providing the documentation necessary to meet all the standards. However, I am happy to support the provisions of the bill because I am aware that consultation has taken place between the states and the territories. Therefore, I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the minister in his second reading speech, the two road transport reform bills before this parliament—the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill—are part of the regime of reformed road transport law being developed by Commonwealth, state and territory governments and the National Road Transport Commission to produce improvements in road safety and transport efficiency, as well as reductions in the costs of administering road transport.

SPEECH.PARA: They are very laudable goals and while I have no argument with many of these reforms, I wish to point out some of the downsides of these bills, particularly the heavy vehicles registration bill. The National Road Transport Commission argues that operators of articulated vehicles will enjoy most of the benefits of these reforms. The commission also argues that massive savings to our national transport costs will accrue from these reforms. However, it also admits much work needs to be done on our national bridge network, for the increased heavy vehicle limits that will come with these reforms, in combination with the new air suspension system, will not be user friendly to bridges.

One wonders if these larger, heavier vehicles will reduce transport costs on the one hand but leave a legacy of taxpayer‐funded damage to our road and bridge system, thereby offsetting the benefits of such reduced transport costs. I believe there are already questions being raised about the claims made about the so‐called road friendliness of the air suspensions.

The minister speaks of national uniformity with the introduction of these reforms but there is precious little uniformity in registration charging to date. Farmers will carry the burden of increased registration charges in New South Wales where charges are now well above those of other states. For example, a rigid truck with a gross vehicle mass limit over 20 tonnes, configuration code 2R4, now costs $2,000 to register in New South Wales, just $187 in Victoria, $500 in Queensland and $1,200 in Tasmania.

As the minister pointed out in his second reading speech, the light vehicles agreement signed by heads of government requires the National Road Transport Commission to demonstrate significant net benefits before including light vehicles in the scheme. Due to the high implementation costs which would be incurred by registration authorities and the low estimated benefits, the commission recommended the legislation not be extended to all vehicles at the moment.

However, the Oberon council in my electorate has written to me detailing its concern with the national registration for heavy vehicles. This will impose an extra $11,000 in registration fees on the council, and the only source of funding that can provide this amount is from road maintenance and construction funds for regional and state roads. Hence, the costs to the community and our road network from road spending forgone because of these compliance costs are already becoming obvious.

Large transport operators are the beneficiaries of this bill. By the minister's reckoning there will be a $14 million saving for these operators, but I wonder what will be the costs to the community. The results could well be additional damage to regional, national and state roads caused by increased load limits and a further deterioration to the rural roads network which was never intended to cater for such volumes of heavy traffic.

Again, in my own electorate, concerned residents are calling for the reopening of the Cumnock‐Molong rail branch line, such is their concern over the dangers from giant wheat trucks on local council roads, the dangers they pose and the obvious damage they cause to both sealed and unsealed roads.

The industry referred to in the minister's speech is the industry of the large transport operators, certainly not the smaller transport owners with a fleet size of less than 20 trucks. Many of the larger companies with fleet size of greater than 20 vehicles have already received massive benefits over and above those smaller operators. Accredited operators will be spared the frustration, delay, inefficiency and costs associated with differences in regulatory frameworks as they no longer have to comply under the alternative compliance regime.

However, those smaller operators who, for whatever reason, were not able to participate in the pilot schemes, will continue to suffer the frustration, delays, inefficiencies and costs associated with differences in regulatory frameworks and charging mechanisms. This is a lack of uniformity where smaller operators, particularly in country areas, suffer and lose competitive advantage to larger operators. Some operators will thus be targeted, while larger operators will be able to short‐cut or bypass the system through the alternative compliance arrangements. Increased road damage and increased accident rates could more likely be the result than the opposite.

There is debate about the representation of community groups on the deliberations that led to these amendments. I will recount a situation in my electorate over the last few years, where community action resulted in the total reform of a stretch of highway at Mt Lambie, near Lithgow, as a result of several serious truck accidents. Not only was that road reformed after several tragedies, but the total loading arrangements for wool bales was reformed thanks to the efforts of the people on the ground who saw a need and raised the pressure at a political level.

BREAK.PARA: Those same people—in my electorate's case the Highway Safety Action Group—sought access to some of the deliberations, just to put in the community point of view and to oversee, if they could, the deliberations that were under way, but they were denied access to the process.

Rail closures—not only of state branches, but the downgrading of the importance of the main western rail line through central New South Wales, for example—have encouraged the growth of the massive and politically powerful transport industry. The rail access charges of the New South Wales state government are out by a factor of four, according to my information from TNT.

In fact, the state government of New South Wales, it seems, is expecting the road transport operators who want to use rail to contribute in a very vast way to the infrastructure. I think it is going about it in entirely the wrong way. The government has a responsibility to provide that infrastructure, but not to charge rail access charges that are a distinct and deliberate disincentive, I believe, to keep more heavier and bulkier materials on road instead of rail.

Most of the visionary truck operators that I speak with want an integrated rail‐road network. They do not want to be forced onto road exclusively. The state government in New South Wales particularly should seriously reconsider just what sorts of returns it wants to get from its rail system.

For all the rhetoric that safer roads and alternative compliance and bigger trucks means fewer trucks and, therefore, savings in transport costs, the real cost of not using rail is not factored into the equation. For all the regulations on hazardous goods included in the second bill under debate here, for all the reassurances to the community about the sorts of standards we will introduce to safeguard communities, and particularly other road users, the fact remains that the vast amount of long haul of hazardous goods should be done by rail.

It would be churlish of me to ignore the benefits which the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill will have on the road transport industry and the general community—albeit most of the dangerous goods should be on rail. The repeal of the current definition of `dangerous goods'—which currently reads `a substance or article prescribed by regulations as dangerous goods'—is a sound move, reading, as it will, `a substance or article determined by a competent authority in accordance with the regulations to be dangerous goods'. This will add that extra degree of security in the transport of dangerous and hazardous materials that, to a greater or lesser degree, has had too much of the `she'll be right mate' attitude about it to date.

So too, the widening of regulations concerning the marking and packaging of both goods and vehicles carrying dangerous goods. So too I welcome—and so will the community—the extension of transport to include packing, loading and unloading. The other proposed paragraphs, amending powers to make regulations over routes and times that dangerous goods can travel; the licensing of vehicles and drivers; and the approval by competent authorities of dangerous goods packages, are welcome and overdue reforms.

Item 16, repealing the right of the representative of a corporation to refuse to answer questions on the grounds of self-incrimination but retaining individual rights, is also welcomed, but one wonders if one can cancel out one right and leave the other. It goes somewhere towards tightening corporate responsibility for actions that do jeopardise the safety of the road user, and the general public. Item 18 follows this theme, providing much tougher penalties for corporations rather than individual drivers, for it ultimately is the responsibility of the company consigning such goods.

I commend the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 to the House with the reservations about transport of dangerous goods by road as opposed to rail that I have previously outlined. I have not the same level of enthusiasm at all for the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996 for the reasons I have also detailed. It takes this industry down the path of self-regulation and favours the major operators at the expense of the smaller, including local transporters and farmers amongst those smaller operators.
Let us have uniformity, but also inclusivity. I suggest the road to alternative compliance, while lowering administrative costs to some, could end up costing the community far more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to also support the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996. I do not share the same concerns the member for Calare (Mr Andren) has just mentioned in relation to the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996 and I will come back to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: I will begin by talking about the first of these two bills, the one referring to dangerous goods transportation. The 1995 act was designed to ensure that the transportation of dangerous goods is carried out with maximum safety and efficiency. The act authorises officers, and gives them quite strong powers, to enforce safety rules and, in particular, uniform rules.

We have all seen the consequences of a chemical spill on a road either in a built‐up area or in regional Australia. It is potentially extraordinarily dangerous. We have seen road accidents where noxious substances have spilt from the transport onto roadways and then into streams. In fact, last year there were examples where streams were contaminated by noxious substances, the result of a transport accident. We have seen fires and dangerous gas leaks when transports carrying dangerous substances have been involved in accidents.

Obviously, no bill, no piece of legislation, is going to entirely rule out problems to do with human error. Accidents will always happen, but a bill like this can go far in ensuring that we have regulations that are sensible. We have officers authorised to act in a way that ensures that they can enforce the rules. Therefore, I am very supportive, like others, of this particular amendment. In fact, this 1996 amendment, which is a technical refinement to the bill, will help to ensure that we have some of the most stringent dangerous goods transportation regulations in the world.

In relation to the other bill, the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996, the key is that it will establish a national registration scheme for heavy vehicles throughout Australia. This is an essential component of the road transport reform now being developed in cooperation with the states, the territories, the Commonwealth, the National Road Transport Commission and, most importantly of all, the industry itself.

We can see that this bill ushers in a new era where, as a government, we do not simply employ rules and regulations and the big stick to ensure that they are complied with. We understand the essential nature of cooperation, coordination and consultation with industry. This bill is very much a consequence of a collaborative approach. In fact, our minister will be continuing that collaboration in the next few weeks with transport industry consultations in Hobart.

BREAK.PARA: With the new Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996 we at last see sensible, rational, nationally consistent legislation. In my electorate our local economy is dependent on road transport. Unlike the member for Calare's experience, I have had overwhelming congratulations and support from the industry for these amendments.

The road transport industry in Australia is an essential link in the chain connecting suppliers to buyers in all states. In Australia, the motor‐vehicle transport industry has been particularly important because we are such a vast continent and most of us do not have direct access to waterways. We are dependent on our roads. Our rail system is not a network that gives us adequate access to fast and efficient transport. There are too few kilometres of rail, with inefficiencies there that we are still dealing with. It is road transport that we depend on to a very large extent.

Each summer sees rivers of grain, for example, flow off the farms onto the roads and on to the rail heads or down to the wharfs. As the member for Calare mentioned, a lot of those wheat transports are only small in comparison with some of the road trains we are familiar with in Australia, but they are a very essential part of the efficiency of the industry. The transportation of that wheat needs to be conducted in a safe and efficient manner and if there are nationally consistent regulations we can expect to see our farm produce, in particular, more cost‐effectively and efficiently transported.

We are amongst the world's most cost‐effective dairy exporters. But a very substantial part of that cost efficiency is affected by the costs involved in transporting the raw milk off the farms to the manufacturing centres. With the plethora of red tape and regulation inconsistencies of the past, our road transport industry has not been as cost efficient as it needs to be.

Every few cents added to a litre of milk, for example, makes us less export competitive; it makes us less competitive on our domestic markets, where we face competition from the New Zealand product and from the other overseas imported product, too often subsidised or on the verge of being dumped here. So this bill makes a very significant contribution to the economy of Australia. As well, it deals with issues of safety for those who are involved directly in driving our transports, for those who encounter the transports on the roads and those who are involved with loading vehicles and unloading.

Ever since motorised trucking took over from the bullocks and horse wagons in Australia, we have had to contend with cross‐border inefficiencies. It is a legacy of our colonial past that every colony took, perhaps, in some senses, a great delight in ensuring that often they had their own quite idiosyncratic rules and regulations about things like the cost of registration, lighting required, allowable tonnages, safety requirements, speeds and so on when it came to vehicular transport.

We have seen transport operators actually shopping around from state to state to see which offers the cheapest and the most sensible regulatory regimes before they set up their businesses and apply for registrations. What a waste of time, a waste of mental effort, in having to do that. Even if the work of the transport operators was located in another state, we have seen businesses establish elsewhere.

From time to time we have also seen the appalling time loss and added cost of valuable, fragile road freight being unloaded and reloaded at the borders, because the transport was not designed or registered in a way that is acceptable in the state next door. That is just an absurdity, and it has existed for far too long in Australia. At last we have a resolution of some of those absurdities.

As I mentioned before, this bill also signposts a new, cooperative, highly productive relationship between government and industry, one of the most important industry sectors in the nation. The road transport forum in my electorate, the Goulburn Valley Road Transport Forum, is an industry sector that I work with most closely. Right now, together, we are identifying the particular road hazards that may be funded under the black spot program with federal funding moneys. That road transport forum, representative of small and large operators, knows that in this government it has a voice. We are working together to make sure that absurdities like eight different legislative, regulatory regimes will never happen again.

This bill is about reducing costs as well as about safety and consistency. We have to see in Australia where we can cut costs at every corner. Our government is committed to reducing regulatory red tape. It is amazing that some 20 per cent of the cost of all supermarket items tends to be a reflection of the transportation costs of getting those products onto the shelves. That is too much. At a time when we are seeing our market share of exported agricultural products decline, we have to see where we can assist our transport industry to sustain itself, grow and flourish.

Nowhere is this legislation more welcomed than in regional Australia, in particular in my electorate of Murray. We are the only place in Australia which still has a processing fruit canneries sector, with two manufacturers—SPC and Ardmona—continuing to export and to thrive on the domestic market. We are totally dependent on road transportation of fruit to the factory and product to the wharves. Likewise, we are also the centre of Australia's dairy manufacturing, which is totally dependent on road transportation. Those industries are of such significance in our electorate that some 56 per cent of all employment in the Goulburn Valley is directly related to the transport sector. In fact, some 20 per cent of all road transports in Australia are registered in the Goulburn Valley and take the agriproduct—some 100 per cent of all Australian canned fruit and some 70 per cent of all dairy product—to the wharves.

Some 1.7 per cent of all employment in Australia is related directly to the truck transport industry and that industry grew by some 21 per cent between 1985 and 1993—an addition of 22,000‐plus jobs. We owe this industry a lot of respect. We owe it the best possible regulatory framework that any nation can produce, and in this bill we see the beginnings of major road transport reform. Yes, there is still some way to go with the smaller, lighter vehicles; that is still in the process of being worked out with industry. The industry understands that this government is committed to total reform.

Each year our road transport sector shifts freight worth some $60 billion. From time to time, we hear of horrendous trucking accidents where the drivers of the transports that are transporting such incredible volumes and value of freight have accidents. We often hear that those accidents are due to the fact that they have driven for too long, at too great a speed, and sometimes the taking of some medications has been involved. We would hope that regulations that are consistent nationally, like these, will help to overcome the health risks associated with driving and being involved in the transport sector. In particular, we will expect to see that road safety factors for all comers, both transport drivers and those who encounter the huge transports on the roads, are improved.

I am interested in the suggestion by the member for Calare that the increase that has been talked about in the size or mass of transports in the future will be at a major cost to the domestic economy. Yes, there is a problem with our bridges. No‐one denies that this country has been starved of road funding for the last 13 years. We have the most appalling situation where initially, when we—the coalition—introduced the whole business of federal road taxes, some 70 per cent of that excise was returned to road construction and maintenance. Unfortunately, under Labor, the proportion returned to road and bridge maintenance dropped to just seven per cent.

Yes, we know the bridges are in a shocking state; we know they will need to be upgraded. It will be a challenge for this government and this nation to try and find those funds in an extraordinarily difficult economic environment. On the other hand, we cannot pull back from having an efficient transport industry. When our economic export efficiency is dependent on efficient road transport, we cannot hold back the evolution of road transport industry development because there is a fear that some bridges might not take it. What we have to do is deal with both of these issues.

I am concerned that, with the condition of the current economy, we may not have the funds for the duplication of the Goulburn Valley Highway. However, I am assured by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) that he will do all in his power to see that the Goulburn Valley Highway will receive the funding for duplication. In the last 10 months we have seen 11 deaths on the unduplicated Goulburn Valley Highway, which has some of the highest levels of heavy road transport moving up and down it. Most of those accidents, which took out young families, involved trucks colliding with smaller family sedans.

I acknowledge the concerns of the member for Calare (Mr Andren) about the condition of our roads and bridges. This legislation is dealing with an efficient, cost‐effective road transport sector. We have to deal with finding funding for our roads in an extraordinary environment. Our problem at the moment is the legacy, as I say, of our proportion of road excise over the years being turned into a greater proportion of general revenue.

Today, I have great pleasure in supporting these two bills, the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996. Certainly regional Australia is dependent on the road transport sector being efficient and effective. All of Australia is dependent on safe roads. These bills will go a long way to achieving those ends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 makes a number of technical drafting amendments to the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act 1995, which established a national regulatory scheme for the transport of dangerous goods by road. I am very pleased that the legislation initially governing this area of road transport activity was brought to bear by Labor in power.

SPEECH.PARA: We certainly had a vision to standardise the myriad of regulations relating to the transport of dangerous goods, which had evolved over time because of differing state jurisdictions. As the shadow minister mentioned in his remarks, the bill makes a number of amendments clarifying powers to make regulations, and it reflects changes in terminology arising from those proposed amendments. The opposition does not oppose the measures in this bill.

In the context of this debate on the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996, I would like to raise a matter of considerable concern to the electors of Corio. That matter relates to the transport of dangerous goods on the Princes Highway, which links the provincial city of Geelong with metropolitan Melbourne. This stretch of highway is one of the busiest in Victoria and it is used by many thousands of commuters both ways each day. With the opening of the western ring road, commercial and other traffic on the Geelong‐Melbourne highway has increased considerably.

BREAK.PARA: I am led to believe that the traffic on the western ring road, as I speak in this place today, is at a level in 1997 that it was anticipated by the experts to be at in the year 2006. That is quite a staggering statistic which has quite profound implications for economic geographers and city planners as they plot the future development of Melbourne and its environs, Geelong and its environs, and the rest of the state.

Existing transport infrastructure, and the economics of moving freight around greater metropolitan Melbourne is pushing greater traffic and commercial activity into Melbourne's west and into the Melbourne‐Geelong corridor. As I said, this will have quite an effect on the location of future economic activity in that Melbourne‐Geelong corridor, and makes a case for a third lane on the Princes Highway between Geelong and Melbourne even more compelling. Sadly, with all the expertise available to the Victorian government, the government of Premier Kennett has yet to appreciate some of the substantial changes that are occurring because of the way in which the transport infrastructure is now generating economic activity.

Recent reports published by the Victorian government on Melbourne's transport needs show that, according to the government, the network stops at the outer environs in the west and does not encompass the whole of the Port Phillip Bay area. Indeed, we ought to be looking at this whole area as an economic zone and looking for an integrated transport infrastructure that will deliver more efficient economic outcomes for the state and the nation in the longer term. Labor, under One Nation, commenced the task of upgrading the transport infrastructure in this area of the state of Victoria with the construction of the western ring‐road and its linkage with the Princes Highway, and the construction of a third lane of several kilometres on the Princes Highway leading out of Geelong. As has always been the case, it has been a Labor government with the vision to see the need for these projects and to commit the resources to bring them to fruition.

Of course, the increase in traffic in the Geelong‐Melbourne corridor has implications for the transport of dangerous goods and for the regulation of heavy vehicular traffic flows between the two cities of Geelong and Melbourne. Geelong is a manufacturing city. It produces a range of products, such as explosives, petroleum, paints and other substances that rely on the input of toxic chemicals and other dangerous substances. The transport of these substances poses quite serious risks to workers and businesses using the highway on a regular basis each day. Local and state media regularly carry stories of oil and other chemical spills on this highway. It is these spills which cause severe disruption to the flow of commercial and private traffic over that stretch of the highway.

Therefore, it is with great alarm and concern that the Geelong community views the Kennett government's proposal to relocate the Coode Island chemicals complex to Point Lillias near Geelong. The proposal is opposed on a number of significant grounds, one of which is the public hazard that will eventually flow from an increase on the Melbourne‐Geelong highway of heavy vehicular traffic carrying dangerous chemicals to the proposed storage facility.

Already, around 30,000 vehicles travel every day over the Princes Highway and that stretch that I have explained, and double that number travel between Werribee and Melbourne. It is estimated that, with the construction of the East Coast Armaments Complex and the relocation of Coode Island, these developments alone will increase heavy vehicular traffic and truck journeys by around 600 per day, thus creating a huge safety problem for the region.

That safety concern is compounded by the rundown of Geelong's fire fighting capacity by the Kennett government. I met recently with Geelong firefighters, and I heard at first hand how their capacity to protect the public when dangerous chemical spills occur has been diminished by state government cutbacks. The situation would be a dangerously critical one in the case of a major accident at the Point Lillias site.

I commend the firefighters of Geelong for their dedication to their profession and to the Geelong community. They have long argued that these cutbacks are not in the public interest. They argue that case not from a selfish point of view in terms of protecting their employment but from the realities of the resources that are being made available by the state government and the myriad tasks they are now called upon to perform. We need a firefighting capacity that can respond quickly to accidents and protect the travelling public, and we do not have it at the moment. These public road safety concerns are but some of many that the Geelong community has with regard to the establishment of a petroleum and chemical storage facility at Point Lillias. The power to stop the Point Lillias development lies with the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, who is currently considering this matter.

The Commonwealth has an international obligation under the Ramsar convention to protect the Point Lillias area as a habitat for endangered migratory bird species such as the orange bellied parrot. Now that might not seem so significant to many and, indeed, the Victorian Premier does not consider it so. He regards the orange bellied parrot as just another trumped up corella. Any environmental vandal or environmental imbecile, which I suspect the Victorian Premier is, should appreciate that endangered bird species are a matter of international concern. They are a matter of international negotiation and a convention, which Australia has signed, to protect the wetlands of these very important and endangered species.

So the Point Lillias area is a wetland area of international significance and I urge Senator Hill again, on behalf of the Geelong community, to exercise his Commonwealth powers and stop the Point Lillias development. The Victorian government's proposal to excise 20 hectares from the Point Lillias area currently protected by Ramsar to achieve the Coode Island relocation must be rejected by Senator Hill. Above all, Australia's international reputation in environmental matters must be protected. If the Point Lillias development proceeds, as I explained, the traffic of dangerous chemicals and dangerous goods on that stretch of highway between Melbourne and Geelong will be increased substantially.

It is, therefore, with considerable concern that I noted the recent letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to Senator Hill, apparently endorsing the Victorian government's position on Point Lillias, and stating to Senator Hill, `You are in a position to respond expeditiously to the Victorian request'. It would seem to me that the Prime Minister is indeed endorsing the Point Lillias development and it is one which will compound the difficulties that we already face on the Princes Highway with the carriage of dangerous goods.
My esteemed colleague the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) pointed out in her press release of 30 January 1997:
It is clear that Senator Hill's own bureaucrats do not consider the Victorian government's submission has clearly demonstrated the relocation is in the urgent national interest.

That is the only basis on which the Victorian government can argue that this 20 hectares ought to be excised from the Ramsar protected areas for Coode Island to be relocated to Point Lillias. Indeed, those bureaucrats that I mentioned before have been sent away to prop up the Victorian submission and to come up with a new position that is defensible in the international arena.

Might I remind the Prime Minister and Senator Hill that the Geelong community has a strong and different view of how this area ought to be developed. The Prime Minister, Senator Hill and cabinet ministers are aware of proposals to develop Avalon airport and its environs as a dedicated freight centre for the export of fresh produce to Asia. The government has already leased the airport to the Foxerco consortium, and trucking magnate Lindsay Fox, who is a key player in that consortium, has endorsed the Avalon vision. It is poised for massive development. The employment gains to the region are estimated at over 5,000. The gains to the national export effort and to the balance of payments are estimated in the billions of dollars.

It is in the urgent national economic interest that the Avalon development proceed and the Victorian government's proposal to locate a chemical storage complex in the Point Lillias area is squashed. The Prime Minister knows of the implications of the decision that must be made with regard to the Point Lillias development. As I mentioned, it is this Point Lillias development that is going to exacerbate the problem that we already have on the highway with regard to the transport of dangerous goods, which is the subject of the bill before this Main Committee.

I refer the Prime Minister to a letter that was sent to him on 2 February by Ross Mellor, the facilitator and coordinator of the Habitat Trust, in which he points the Prime Minister to the implications of the decisions that are about to be made by the federal government on land use in this whole area. I commend Mr Mellor and Mr Elio Comello of the Habitat Trust for the excellent work they have done in elevating the Avalon proposal—the vision that the Geelong community has for this area of the state—in the halls of the state and federal governments.
Mr Mellor has this to say to the Prime Minister:

We wish to state to you that there are a number of the members of your Cabinet who are acutely aware that the establishment of the chemical facility at Point Lillias adjacent to Avalon Airport Geelong will directly, injuriously and adversely mitigate against the establishment of the Australian National Fresh Food export system now being established at Avalon Airport, the sale of which has been confirmed to Foxerco Pty Ltd. . .

Fresh food is the key to a major national export system and apparent contamination by association with a chemical facility will directly and seriously affect the export capability through the Avalon airport. The extent of this project and what is at stake can best be represented by estimated employment and gross export values within seven years of now—

And Mr Mellor is a little more expansive in the employment gains that he claims will be achieved at Avalon—70,000 in south‐east Australia—and exports over a 10‐year period of $45 billion to $55 billion. He concludes his letter to the Prime Minister with the statement:

It is very clear that the `urgent national interest' requires that the Point Lillias chemical facility not be proceeded with and all associated with the major national export project trust that you comprehend the national significance of the issue.

I draw the Prime Minister's attention to the alternatives that are there in the way that this area of land around Avalon airport might be used. The Prime Minister can support a Victorian government proposal that is going to see the relocation of a chemical storage facility to Point Lillias, with employment gains that are estimated at 60—I repeat, 60—or the Prime Minister can choose in the national interest to pursue a development at Avalon airport which we conservatively estimate will deliver 5,000 jobs in the immediate environs and contribute massively to the national export effort.

In the Geelong Advertiser only today, an economist, Mr Francis Grey, in a brief prepared by his organisation, Economists at Large and Associates, said this about the relocation of the chemical facility at Coode Island to Point Lillias:
Relocating the chemical facility would risk industry opportunities that were likely to offer `greater wealth creating potential and hence significant sustainable employment'.
So there is an economist saying that the choices to the government are quite clear and they are very stark indeed.

The Prime Minister and his cabinet colleagues can walk the road of a proposal that merely props up an inadequate and unsubstantial submission by the Victorian government on Point Lillias or it can opt for a benign economic development, an environmentally compatible economic development, that will deliver staggering gains to the national economy and to the local regional economy. The upshot for the Geelong region of the Prime Minister and his colleagues making a decision on the former is that not only will the region be shortchanged and not only will the nation be shortchanged but the important stretch of highway between Geelong and Melbourne will be clogged up with heavy vehicular transport carrying dangerous chemicals and endangering the public that use that road every day.

As I mentioned, there is already a compelling case now, with the developments that have occurred with the expansion of the western ring road activity, for a third lane to be built on the highway between Geelong and Melbourne.

The government must look seriously at this now and it must commence its budgetary planning to give effect to this infrastructure development over the next five years. That development will be important to the economic growth of the state of Victoria and indeed to the national economy especially if the Avalon development is given a fair go by this government.

Senator Hill knows the implications, the Prime Minister knows the implications and the minister for transport knows the implications of the decisions that are already now on the deck and facing this cabinet. I hope in the interests of the Geelong community that the correct decision is made. I hope in the interests of the national economy that the government shows some good sense and backs away from the tacit approval that the Prime Minister has given to the Kennett government Point Lillias proposal and supports a development that will deliver such substantial economic benefits to the national economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to commend to the House the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996. This bill clarifies a number of issues that have up until now been misconstrued or taken for granted and have been found wanting.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all aware of the term `dangerous goods'. It means different things to different people, but it pleases me to see that a competent authority will now make that decision in respect of specific subject matter, in accordance, of course, with the regulations.

It is also very good to see that the regulations now impose a duty of care on manufacturers of dangerous goods to be transported and of vehicles and containers that are being used to convey such goods by road.

If every care is taken by all parties involved in the transportation of dangerous goods, from packaging to storage, vehicles to drivers and of course on the road, then we will be able to maintain a very low accident ratio.

BREAK.PARA: This bill imposes the requirement on the parties involved, from the bottom to the top, and will ensure safety is a prerequisite of all aspects of transporting the goods from one place to another.
`Dangerous goods' can be classified as both live and dead, but potentially all of them have the capacity to create a natural disaster of momentous proportions.

Dangerous goods such as explosives, gas and fuel, and radioactive materials are regularly used in our everyday existence and have to be transported all over the country on a daily basis. The forms of transport we use demand that these goods are transported in large quantities, and because of this any accident has the potential to be catastrophic, no matter whether it occurs on an isolated highway or in a busy town centre.

Our roads are not necessarily always safe. Nearly 2,000 people die on our roads from motor vehicle accidents every year. This does not include those accidents which only result in injury or where no injury occurs and only damage is caused.

When it comes to dangerous goods, any of these scenarios will cause a very serious problem and the best trained, equipped and operated emergency teams from the ambulance and fire services will not be able to prevent a major accident involving dangerous goods from happening or from causing serious problems.

We have all seen the damage and destruction that can occur when an oil tanker leaks its load into the ocean; especially from an environmental point of view we have all seen what can happen to a community when bushfires get out of control. However, a considerable number of dangerous goods that are transported on our roads every day can cause a far greater catastrophe in our communities. We cannot allow this to happen and this bill goes a long way to ensure that all proper precautions are taken by the responsible parties involved in the transportation of dangerous goods and any abuse of this act will result in very heavy penalties.

Another praiseworthy amendment to the bill is the replacement of subsection 42(5) which now requires that a company must actually be convicted of an offence against the act before a director of the company may be deemed liable for that offence, with the requirement that the company must have committed the offence.

If a company is found guilty of an offence against the act, then the company director must be held responsible and should not be able to avoid liability. This alone will ensure that all precautions are taken, and preventative measures are put in place to safeguard the company and its directors. As a consequence of this amendment we will see company directors making sure every aspect of their operation is as foolproof as can be, and all rules and regulations are abided by. This amendment alone will enhance the safety criteria of the transportation of dangerous goods industry overnight.

The amendments to this bill will also give the competent authority the ability to allow regulations to be made both to the licensing of vehicles and drivers for the purpose of transporting dangerous goods, and to the licensing of people responsible for the transport of dangerous goods or for vehicles used in that transport. This amendment will ensure that the issue of safety is the responsibility of all licensed parties involved in the transportation of goods, and will provide a number of checks and balances.

Safety has to be the most important issue when it comes to the transportation of dangerous goods. Our major roads are very busy thoroughfares and our minor roads are often in a state of disrepair. Therefore, it is imperative that every conceivable action is taken to prevent any form of accident from occurring. With all parties involved in the transportation of goods properly accredited and responsible professionals, the risk of potential accidents on our highways and byways is reduced.

Australia has a massive road transport system, on most of which, as the general public sees it, potential accidents are waiting to happen. It is in turn thought by many that more of the dangerous goods distributed through this great nation should be on the rail system, and I must say that this is a hard point to argue. However, with possible industry changes and changes in perceptions within the rail system this may become reality in the future.

These amendments now give a breath of fresh air that, should an accident occur, the necessary emergency crews can be contacted immediately to bring the response times to an absolute minimum, this assistance coming from the fact that any of the travelling public will now be able to immediately recognise the threat posed by the goods of carriage. The threat is what the emergency services crew need to know so that, regardless of how far this crew have to travel, they will know the plan of attack that is required in order to render the dangerous goods safe. This information comes from a simple system of placarding which is long overdue.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the carriage of liquid petroleum gas, this being one of the most dangerous goods we have on today's roads. In the event of an accident, a subsequent fire brings on the danger of a BLEVE, a boiling liquid expanding vapour explosion. Should some LPG gas cylinders become heated and explode, the potential to kill those standing in the vicinity becomes very real. This legislation provides immediate information to the emergency services of the threat, in turn sending a clear and concise message to the emergency services of the possible need to evaluate the immediate area, street or even suburb.

The legislation will save lives and I commend the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) for having the foresight to listen to the industry and to give it what it wants, not what some bureaucrat in an office says, who has no knowledge of what is really required. I commend to the House the amendments to the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Urban Flood Mitigation Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 11 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Commonwealth funding was provided to the Urban Flood Mitigation Program prior to 2 March 1996.
(2) Has the Urban Flood Mitigation Program been successful in providing the infrastructure to combat severe flooding and its effects in the south western region of Sydney.
(3) Is there still a considerable amount of work and funding needed in south western Sydney to make areas flood resistant.

(4) Has federal funding to the Urban Flood Mitigation been reduced; if so, will the Government provide disaster relief should south western Sydney be affected by floods of similar severity as experienced in the area in 1986 and 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Nil. During 1995/96 Commonwealth assistance for urban flood mitigation was primarily administered under the National Landcare Program as part of general assistance for floodplain management. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is responsible for the National Landcare Program. There was no separate treatment of "urban flood mitigation" versus "rural flood mitigation" under the National Landcare Program in 1995/96 nor in the earlier years of operation of this Program.

(2) Assistance for urban floodplain management was the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy until the end of 1995/96. Urban flood elements of the National Landcare Program and associated funds were transferred to my Department for inclusion in the Urban Flood Mitigation Program which was due to begin operation in 1996/97. As you know, the Commission of Audit reported on this matter and the Government subsequently abolished the Program as a savings measure in the Budget context.

(3) My advice is that work is ongoing in urban floodplain management with the support of the NSW Government and local governments. This issue is essentially one of State and local government responsibility.

(4) As a result of the program rationalisation measures the Government has had to make, the funds available for urban flood mitigation will be less than in recent years. However, through the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements (NDRA) administered by the Department of Finance, the Commonwealth will continue to provide reimbursement for State expenditure on a range of eligible relief measures, where State expenditure exceeds an agreed funding threshold under the NDRA formula. In the event of severe future flooding in the south western Sydney area, Commonwealth funding assistance will continue to be available, provided that the disaster meets the eligibility criteria under the NDRA determination.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Protective Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 15 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Government's attitude in regard to the core business and tendering practices of the Australian Protective Service (APS) and how has this attitude changed since 2 March 1996.
(2) Has the APS been prohibited from tendering against the private sector for building security work.
(3) For which APS work has the Government allowed the private sector to engage in competitive tendering.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government believes it is important that there be an assessment of the appropriateness of the Commonwealth's involvement with commercial business units such as the APS. The Government is awaiting the results of a review of the APS. Until this review is complete and recommendations are made to the Government, it would be inappropriate to signal any change in attitude to organisations such as the APS.

(2) The function of the Australian Public Service, as defined in section 6 of the Australian Protective Service Act 1987, is to provide protective and custodial services for and on behalf of the Commonwealth as the Minister directs.There are, therefore, statutory, constitutional and Ministerial limits on the functions of the APS but they are not prohibitions as such. Each case is examined on its merits to establish whether it falls within statutory and constitutional bounds. Where that is the case, I may direct that a particular matter may be undertaken as a function of the APS.

(3) The security services for the National Crime Authority were untied from the APS by the former Government. The NCA put services to tender and these were awarded to a private sector firm. This is the only work previously done by the APS that has been awarded to the private sector at this stage.
